description: Using grapes sourced from 70-year-old vines, this has a wood element that combines with citrus and yellow fruits. An apple flavor melds with a menthol note, bringing out herbal and fruity characters. On the finish, the concentration from the old vines shows strongly.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2010 Vieilles Vignes  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: A broad, spicy wine, ripe with plenty of sweet mango and peach fruits to go with the green fruit acidity. It is already delicious but will develop further over the next 2-3 years.
title: Château de Chamirey 2008 La Mission Premier Cru  (Mercurey)

description: Well structured wine with plenty of ripe fruit. The freshness of fruit is replaced by spice and peach flavors.
title: Château de Fuissé 2008 Le Clos  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Soft and creamy, with a good touch of wood, ripe apples and a line in citrus and honey. Rounded, attractive.
title: Château de Fuissé 2008 Les Brulés  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Rich, buttery and forward, but with a fine streak of minerality to give structure and interest. The wood gives a spicy character to the wine, but it doesn't dominate the rich burst of fruit.
title: Etienne Sauzet 2004  Puligny-Montrachet

description: Château de Meursault almost always produces powerful wines. That fact plus the ripe 2003 vinatge has yielded a huge premier cru. White stone fruits dominate, but the toast isn't far behind. Has good structure, too, promising development over 5 years. Imported by Cannon Wines Limited.
title: Château de Meursault 2003 Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: New wood overwhelms the aromas, and it also dominates the palate of this wine. It just keeps on the right side of drinkability because the spice merges into pear flavors to give an intriguing nutmeg character, while the aftertaste offers freshness. The wine needs at least a year to blend together.
title: Château de Fuissé 2006 Les Brulés  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Just west of the finest white wine slopes of the Côte de Beaune, Saint-Aubin produces some early drinking crisp wines. This wine comes from one of a series of premier crus with warm yellow fruits and delicate texture. There are touches of toast as well as juicy acidity that are refreshing. Drink this wine from 2018.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2014 Charmois Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: Aromas of this wine show considerable wood. On the palate, the wood is very present, giving acidity as well as layers of toast and spice. Hints of yellow fruit show through, suggesting the possibility of a ripe, rich wine in the future. Drink from 2019.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2013 Bastion Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: Round and generous, but with a mineral heart that gives structure to this full wine. It has weight, dense fruit and delicious peach and nectarine flavors. The structure suggests this Morgeot has the potential to age.
title: Louis Latour 2004 Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This structured, tight wine has complex almond and spice flavors that partner with crisp acidity and tangy lemon zest and grapefruit accents. The texture with its minerality and tight aftertaste promises aging. Drink from 2019.
title: Domaine L. Chatelain 2014 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Ripe and creamy in texture, this wine offers mango and pineapple flavors and crisp, citrusy acidity. It's an age-worthy selection, with minerality and a fine texture.
title: Garnier et Fils 2011 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Full and round, this wine is fruity while smooth and rich. A layer of crisp acidity is surrounded by the generous white and yellow fruits, accented by a touch of toast and spice. Drink this wine from 2018.
title: Château de Santenay 2014  Meursault

description: Flavors of high toast wood are very dominant in this wine, and mingle with green herb, ripe pineapple and spice. The acidity cuts through it all, a band of freshness that comes with the structure of green plum skins. It could well age, and will certainly integrate more in the next two years.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2005 Les Caradeux Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: A wine with great fruit and balance, this is totally ready to drink. Harmony between the juicy acidity and yellow fruits gives the wine richness, intensity and an intensely fresh aftertaste.
title: Christophe Cordier 2013 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This wine balances intense fruit with a steely core of minerality. It is packed with apple, crisp pear and kiwi fruits, contrasted with this tight texture and hints of wood aging. Well balanced, the wine will be ready to drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Jean Monnier et Fils 2014  Puligny-Montrachet

description: This is complex and ripe but also mineraly and very structured. It offers many facets of the village: its richness and its strong sense of terroir. Bright, clean and fragrant on the finish.
title: Louis Latour 2010  Puligny-Montrachet

description: Along with all the ripe fruit in the wine, there is a kernel of serious structure. That gives the wine minerality, textured acidity lying over the depth of white fruits. Toast adds extra complexity before a crisp aftertaste.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2009  Puligny-Montrachet

description: This rich wine is full of spice and cream, with a soft texture. The ripe fruit with its tropical and yellow flavors is generous, cut by attractive acidity and a full-bodied aftertaste. Drink from 2020.
title: Jean-Claude Boisset 2015 Sur Gamay Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: In the ripe, opulent style that is characteristic of this producer, this is a full-bore wine. Rich yellow fruits and juicy acidity are given extra richness by the touch of toastiness and spice. Drink this generous wine from 2021.
title: Château de Santenay 2016 La Comme Premier Cru  (Santenay)

description: This is one of six wines from this village made by this producer. It shows its potential for excellent white wines with its ripe, smoky character, rich yellow fruits and crisp texture. With its minerality and acidity, it will age, so drink from 2020.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2015 Champlots Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: Initially soft, this wine's real mineral character only comes through slowly. The wine has richness and weight. Very textured, it could age well for 3-4 years.
title: Alex Gambal 2009  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: This is a dense structured wine with some herbal flavors as well as kiwi and green plums. Fruit dominates, leaving the wood with a walk-on part. It is developing slowly and needs another 2-3 years to open fully.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2004 Champ Gain Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: A lively, fresh wine that gives a steely, mineral edge to the ripe fruits and the crisp acidity. The wine fills the mouth, a bold streak of apple skin structure boosting the fresh fruits.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2007 Clos Saint-Landry Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: A fine, fruity but structured wine. It brings together many attractive elements of crisp fruits, ripe peaches, toast and a definite tight structure for aging. Keep for 2-3 years.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2007  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: The wine is soft and rounded. With creamed apple and pear flavors over touches of wood, it is a toasty wine in a generous style that has made Meursault popular for many years. Fruity and ripe, the wine will be ready to drink from 2018.
title: Maison Roche de Bellene 2014 Vieilles Vignes  (Meursault)

description: This is a smooth, soft wine with good apple and pear fruit. Restrained wood supports the ripeness and the lightly mineral texture. From one of the line of great premier crus in the appellation, it is likely to age well. Drink from 2019.
title: Patriarche Pére et Fils 2013 Sous Blagny Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Named after the lime trees that grew around this vineyard, this wine is structured with great minerality as well as tight citrus fruit. It has potential with its tense acidity and hints of apricot flavors. Don't drink before 2021.
title: Domaine Berthelemot 2016 Les Tillets  (Meursault)

description: This Becky Wasserman selection is bright, tangy and full of fruit. Apples and crisp pear flavors come through the spiciness to give an attractive, ripe biodynamic wine from the highest and stoniest part of the vineyard slope. It has a delicious aftertaste of fragrant citrus and minerality. The 2014 vintage is dedicated to Marc-Antoine Bret.
designation: Domaine la Soufrandiére Climat Les Quarts
title: Bret Brothers 2014 Domaine la Soufrandiére Climat Les Quarts  (Pouilly-Vinzelles)

description: Le Clos Blanc is a rarity in the mainly red vineyards of Beaune, a patch of chalky soil that has long been planted with Chardonnay. This 2003 is an open wine, with touches of almond and toast flavors, leaving a fresh aftertaste of acidity and green plums. Imported by Kobrand.
designation: Le Clos Blanc Beaune Gréves Premier Cru
title: Louis Jadot 2003 Le Clos Blanc Beaune Gréves Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: With its upfront, ripe apple and pear flavors, this wine is immediately attractive. Behind the fruitiness, there is a firm, structured character of minerality and a steely edge, which makes this a Chardonnay to age for 3-4 years.
title: Domaine Charly Nicolle 2011 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Ripe, open and packed with melon and tropical fruit flavors, this wine is already showing enticing drinkability. Its fresh, ripe fruits is layered with some mineral character and an under-cushion of wood.
title: Louis Latour 2004 Cailleret Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: The touches of wood in this wine are subtle and fragrant. With apple acidity and a crisp texture that balances the wood, the wine is ripe while totally fresh. It is likely to develop over the next few months. Drink from 2017.
title: Alex Gambal 2014  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: Taut and tightly textured, this young wine is packed with citrus and apple flavors. It has weight and the potential to age. Beautifully crisp, refreshing as well as rich, the wine will be ready to drink from 2020.
designation: Closerie des Alisiers Terroir de Meursault
title: Maison Stéphane Brocard 2017 Closerie des Alisiers Terroir de Meursault  (Meursault)

description: Round, smooth, this wine lives up to its charming name. Yellow fruits and sweet grapefruit go well together, the wood and acidity showing through the ripeness. Juicy, toasty, the wine has an attractive edge on the finish.
title: Maison Jessiaume 2008 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: A light, floating style, pierced with minerality and crisp green apple skin flavors. There is wood, but it is only just noticeable. With its structure and tense fruit, this is likely to age well: give it 5-8 years.
title: Labouré-Roi 2005 Château Labouré-Roi Premier Cru Poruzot  (Meursault)

description: Well structured, with a strong mineral element, this wine has richness and is packed with peach, apricot and crisp red apple flavors. The wood is already well integrated, a support to the richness of the wine.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2008  Puligny-Montrachet

description: Flinty yet honeyed at the same time, this full-bodied wine delivers concentrated flavors of pear, melon, dried spices and honey. Easy enough to drink now, yet should hold for at least five years despite relatively low acids. Long and silky-textured on the finish. Imported by Monsieur Henri Wine Co.
title: La Chablisienne 2003 Vaudesir Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: An impressively complex wine for one with only a village appellation. There is a definite minerality mixed with lime and other citrus flavors. A hint of wood spice, stone fruits, green plums and a fine concentration. Imported by Robert Kacher Imports. Editors' Choice.
title: Xavier Monnot 2007  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: A delicious touch of honey in this otherwise dry wine gives extra richness to the generous texture with its gentle spice from wood aging and juicy acidity. Ripe but crisp, the wine will be ready from 2019.
title: Thierry et Pascale Matrot 2016  Meursault

description: Wood aromas dominate, but on the palate the toast element is showing good integration with the round, full, white and yellow stone fruit flavors. There is a crisp green apple acidity that comes through to finish, although the toast character stays as well. Imported by Robert Kacher Imports.
title: Xavier Monnot 2007 Le Limozin  (Meursault)

description: This structured, complex Chardonnay is packed with minerality and considerable weight. The tight texture and almost tannic character will soften over the next few months. Full of potential, it's drinkable now but will be so much better from 2017.
title: Chartron et Trébuchet 2013  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: This wine has a mineral texture, cool and crisp. It is packed with citrus and green-apple flavors that give a bright, tight character. At the end, the vanilla flavor from wood aging comes through. Drink from 2019.
title: Louis Max 2015 Grechons Premier Cru  (Ladoix)

description: This is an obvious but delectable white Burgundy. It's smoky and toasty, with upfront oak, yet the wood is amply backed by layers of grilled peaches and citrus. It's ripe and plump and ready to drink now and over the next several years.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2001 Clos des Mouches  (Beaune)

description: Very rich, ripe and packed with new-wood flavors, this is somewhat flashy, but it's still delicious to drink. Sit back and enjoy.
title: Domaine Jacques Prieur 2004 Clos de Mazeray  (Meursault)

description: Big and round, a wine that has lost its early fruit flavors and has begun to develop a full toast and almond character. It has weight and richness, giving a full  experience. It is not for long-term aging.
title: Pascal Bouchard 2006 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: What a delicious, drinkable wine with peach and fresh-fruit flavors, a touch of pineapple and a touch of almonds. Relish the wine now, or enjoy over the next 5 years.
title: Domaine Bernard Moreau et Fils 2004 Champs Gain Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Very rich, still closed up, this is a wine that is packed with toasty wood. The fruit that is developing has flavors of sweet pear and pineapple, while the acidity comes through slowly, softly
title: Louis Latour 2009 Morgeot  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This wood-aged wine is rich, showing lots of spice and toast. Juicy green-fruit flavors are there but are still to show their true ripeness and balanced acidity. Wait for this wine, from the home vineyard of the producer, until 2020.
title: Henri Darnat 2017 Clos du Domaine  (Meursault)

description: Toasty and nutty on the nose, this is a lush, fruit-filled Burgundy that nevertheless retains a sense of minerality amid its baked-apple flavors. It's plump and custardy in texture, with ample power and concentration, turning minerally on the finish.
title: Prosper Maufoux 2003 Les Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: A ripe wine full of minerality and rich white and yellow fruit, this is still young and shows great potential for serious aging. All fruit for now, it's clean and deliciously creamy and bright. Drink from 2020.
title: Nicolas Potel 2015  Meursault

description: There is great richness here. The wine is ripe, concentrated with bright green fruits as well as a good mineral structure.
title: Louis Latour 2009 Château de Blagny  (Meursault-Blagny)

description: Unusually, this premier cru vineyard produces both red and white wines, both of which are made by this domaine. The wine is soft, rounded and with a ripe creamy character. It has plenty of crisp apple and rich pear flavors along with enough acidity to keep it bright and tangy. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Chevillon-Chezeaux 2014 Les Bousselots Premier Cru  (Nuits-St.-Georges)

description: Little Chardonnay grows in Nuits-Saint-Georges but Les Bousselots has both Chardonnay and Pinot Noir. This is a rich wine with a core of tannins as well as rounded, ripe yellow fruits cut with attractive spice and acidity. Drink this wine from 2020.
title: Domaine Chevillon-Chezeaux 2015 Les Bousselots Premier Cru  (Nuits-St.-Georges)

description: One of the trio of great white wine villages in the Côte de Beaune, Puligny-Montrachet makes the most classical wines. This village wine has the best of all worlds with its generous fruit and beautifully taut texture. It's ready to drink but will also age well. Drink now and until 2022.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2012  Puligny-Montrachet

description: A bright, toasty wine, with the ripe fruits of the vintage and characteristics from the wood giving extra richness to this finely structured, mineral-textured wine.
title: Louis Latour 2009 La Garenne  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: A blend of small parcels of premier cru vineyards, this is a wine that offers richness, toast  and a fine core of citrus and yellow berry flavors. The  finish on this finely crafted wine is a structured, green fruit skin flourish. Imported by Robert Kacher Imports.
title: Domaine Laleure-Piot 2007 Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: Aigrots is one of the Beaune premier crus that produces white as well red wines. In its white manifestation, it is full and dense with structure and ripe fruitiness. A rich wine, it has textured white fruits that are underlined by toastiness. Drink from 2017.
title: Albert Morot 2012 Aigrots Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: The wine is structured and concentrated, showing a strong sense of minerality. Citrus and ripe apple fruits are complemented by richer apricot, always cut through with acidity and a tense texture. It needs to age, drink from 2016.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2012  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: Full, soft and rich, this has flavors of ripe yellow fruit and red apple, with a textured edge. The wine is round and layered with delicious acidity. While its already to drink now, it will age for 3-4 years.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2010 Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: A beautifully crisp, steely wine, initially delicate, then revealing depths of citrus and green plum flavors with light toast and the freshest acidity. There is a final spice from wood and tight structure from the fruit. Imported by Robert Kacher Imports.
title: Domaine Marc Morey 2007 Les Blanchots Dessous  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: With its appealing toast and fruit aromas, this is a rich wine. It does keep plenty of steely texture while allowing the yellow fruits, ripe pear and toast to shine. In style it hovers halfway between the ripe, buttery Meursault of the past and the crisper style of today, a fine compromise and ready to drink now.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2013  Meursault

description: Rich fruit balances with a delicious lemon character, touched by spice, finished with grapefruit juice. This is a bright, crisp wine that will be delicious in another year.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2008 Les Gouttes d'Or Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: A blend of many parcels, this wine brings out the character of Meursault, poised between a crisp, mineral style and something much richer. Wood aging has brought out the riper side of the wine, emphasizing apricots as much as citrus. Drink this sumptuous wine from 2020.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2015  Meursault

description: This is a wine that is about tropical fruits, softness and ripeness. It is definitely full-bodied, needing to show its structure, but the spice, toast and yellow fruit flavors are all immediately attractive.
title: Roux Pére et Fils 2005 Les Macherelles Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: A rich but very fresh wine that sings of green and yellow fruit, vibrant acidity and just a hint of wood. Charmes vineyard is one of the best-known in Meursault, and this wine certainly lives up to the meaning of the name. Imported by Clicquot Inc.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2003 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Tight and mineral in character, with grapefruit and touches of new wood to go with the fresh, dominant, taut acidity. The crispness stays right through, giving a bright, citrus aftertaste.
title: Domaine Michel Bouzereau 2008 Le Tesson  (Meursault)

description: Weight and richness here, with attractive acidity, but also a ripe, creamy texture. The wine has some tight tannins, but is much more to do with opulent peaches and cream.
title: Henri de Villamont 2007 Les Caillerets Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: In a rich vintage like 2015, Puligny-Montrachet gives a wonderful broad, elegant and ripe expression of Chardonnay. In this wine, the balance is just right, both crisp and rounded with great citrus and white fruits. Drink from late 2018.
title: Louis Jadot 2015  Puligny-Montrachet

description: This is a rich smooth wine, full of delicious citrus and apple-fruit flavors. It is ripe, still with signs of wood aging that add a juicy character to the wine. It is developing well and should be ready to drink from 2018.
title: Roux Pére et Fils 2014 Champlots Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: Soft butter and vanilla-almond milk mingle with pear and Gala apple aromas and flavors. Accents of thyme and orange blossom add complexity to the bouquet, while woody sweet spice appears in the mouth and sticks around through the long close. Full, creamy and decadent. Only 5,200 bottles produced.
title: Gérard Bertrand 2009 Aigle Royal Chardonnay (Limoux)

description: Soft and round, this is still coming around. Its fruit flavors are muted by wood and spice, although it already shows richness. It will be an opulent, full wine, with deliciously ripe fruits.
title: Domaine Jean Monnier et Fils 2010 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This wine has weight and richness. It is ripe with apricot and peach flavors that are happily balanced by a crisp edge of acidity. Its texture will give it a good future. Drink from 2019.
title: Louis Latour 2015  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: This is a dense and rich wine that shows both smoothness as well as an edgy mineral texture. It's weighty on the palate with ripe white and yellow fruits and a rounded, juicy character. Fruit and wood aging are still coming together, so give it some time. Drink this stylish wine from 2016.
designation: Cuvée Signature Les Chenevottes Premier Cru
title: Bouchard Aîné & Fils 2011 Cuvée Signature Les Chenevottes Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: A Meursault-based domaine that has progressed rapidly in quality under Philippe Ballot. This Genevriéres is a rich, young wine that promises an open, ripe, wood-layered series of flavors in 2 years.
title: Ballot Millot et Fils 2004 Genevriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Blending grapes from around the appellation, this wine is a fine reflection of its structure and minerality. It's rich and full, while keeping plenty of crisp acidity to contrast its creamy texture. It needs to age for another year, so wait until 2018.
title: Louis Jadot 2014  Puligny-Montrachet

description: There are weight and richness here, along with warm yellow fruit and balanced acidity. The wine is ripe with hints of wood aging giving spice and rounding out the fresh, steely character. It's worth aging, so drink from 2017.
title: Domaine Vrignaud 2012 Blanchot Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Rich and structured, this firm wine has concentration from dense white and yellow fruits plus richness from the wood aging. This intense wine is still developing, so drink from 2018.
title: Château de Santenay 2015  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: The lightest touch of wood gives this wine a full, rich character. Weight and density are balanced by the intense acidity. Melon, apricots and citrus are all blended in this ripe wine. Drink from 2018.
title: Château de Santenay 2015  Meursault

description: A burnt character to this wine from the wood aging needs to blow away. Underneath the fruit is ripe, full and rich. It has a finely textured acidity, lemon and ripe pear flavors with an underlying creamed apple flavor. It needs to age to calm down the wood. Drink from 2017.
title: Château de Fuissé 2013 Le Clos  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: For a village wine, this is impressive. The richness and ripeness of the grapes translates into a full wine with white- fruit and spice flavors. But quite properly, there is a fine, poised mineral streak from the chalk soil that gives the wine shape and balance.
title: Domaine Leflaive 2003  Puligny-Montrachet

description: There is ripe, almost tropical, fruit in this powerful wine. But it is still submerged under a cloak of austere minerality, one which promises a long-lived wine. Imported by Kobrand.
title: Louis Jadot 2003 La Garenne Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: The wine has a great balance between its rich fruits and the wood aging. It shows concentration, the ripe peach and apricots full in the mouth and laced with acidity and full-bodied fruitiness. It's both serious and full of charm, a wine that's developing well and should be ready to drink by 2016.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2012  Puligny-Montrachet

description: The wine is soft, developing well with its ripe yellow fruits and accompanying acidity. It has a fine citrus streak of crispness along with the hints of wood aging. The wine will age well over the medium term and will be ready to drink from 2018.
title: Roux Pére et Fils 2014 Les Cortons Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: This comes from the negociant side of Pierre Morey's business. It is full, rich, fat, open and quite opulent. Yes, the acidity and the freshness of the fruit are there, but this is a generous wine that will develop relatively quickly over 2 to 3 years.
title: Morey-Blanc 2004 Bouchéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: A full, rounded wine with yellow fruit and citrus flavors lying over vanilla and toast flavors. This rich wine is ready to drink despite a good touch of minerality to finish.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2004 Marquis de Laguiche  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This is a ripe, wood-aged wine that shows the richer side of Meursault. It's generous with ripe yellow fruits, but balanced and complemented by crisp acidity and hints of toastiness. A fine wine with impeccable structure, it will age well, so drink from 2015.
designation: Cuvée Signature Le Porusot Premier Cru
title: Bouchard Aîné & Fils 2011 Cuvée Signature Le Porusot Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This wine, while rich, has all the minerality and crisp texture associated with the appellation. Wood aging adds spice. It needs some aging, not much, and will be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2015  Puligny-Montrachet

description: Tight and mineral, this still-young wine offers generous yellow fruits as well as crisp, cool acidity. Developing slowly, it has rich potential. Drink from 2020.
title: Albert Bichot 2016  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: This mineral-textured wine is full of fruit while also being crisp and taut. Its lively character belies its weight and intensity. Drink this still-developing wine from 2020.
title: Roux Pére et Fils 2016  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: This wine is ripe, full of yellow fruits and soft acidity. It's creamy and ripe, but cut with orange zest and a mineral texture. It will be ready to drink from 2017.
title: Louis Latour 2014  Meursault

description: This enclave of Chardonnay in the Pinot Noir-dominated Vougeot is a curiosity, but a delicious one. It comes from a parcel of chalky soil, first planted by monks in the 11th century. The wine is soft, ripe, dominated by apricot freshness and sweetness, but keeping an edge of spice and crisp final acidity. Imported by Boisset America. Editors' Choice.
title: Domaine de la Vougeraie 2006 Clos du Prieuré Monopole  (Vougeot)

description: Touched by wood, the wine has fine acidity with bright white fruits and hints of yellow fruits to go with the mineral character as well as the delicious grapefruit edge.
title: Domaine Jacques Prieur 2009 Clos de la Feguine  (Beaune)

description: Rich fruit over a crisp texture gives this wine a balanced character. Ripe with yellow fruits and cut with acidity, it will be delicious when it ages. Drink this still-young wine from 2020.
title: Domaine Buisson Battault 2015 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This is a soft wine, smooth and full with apricots and melons. Toasty wood flavors are balanced by the ripe fruit, the rich texture and light minerality. This opulent wine needs only short aging. Drink from 2020.
title: Domaine de Bellene 2015 Les Forges  (Meursault)

description: Structured wine, packed with acidity, fresh lemon fruits, layered with peach and pineapple. It's a delicious wine, both ripe and tangy.
title: Domaine Dujac 2009 Premier Cru  (Morey-Saint-Denis)

description: Full, rich and round, this is packed with ripe yellow-fruit flavors, layered with toast. It bears a spice note, delicious acidity and a concentrated, open finish. Let it age for 2-3 years, but it is also enjoyable now.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2010 Bouchéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: A complex name for this finely crafted wine. It shows green fruits and oak, some intensity of flavor and a great layer of acidity, cutting through the rich fruits. The finish brings all this acidity forward, giving a classic Chablis minerality.
designation: Les Clos Grand Cru Clos des Hospices dans Les Clos
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2006 Les Clos Grand Cru Clos des Hospices dans Les Clos  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: This ripe and fruity wine has just the right amount of mineral texture to give it a zesty character. It offers hints of toast, attractive juicy acidity and a lively, bright aftertaste. The wine needs to lose the slight earthy flavor from bottling that should soon blow away.
title: Domaine Antonin Guyon 2015 Les Charmes Dessus Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This wine, young but with good potential, is rich, keeping its crisp character in the background. It is still taut and mineral, although that will change into some altogether riper. This generous wine should be kept until 2020.
title: Arnaud Baillot 2016 Le Limozin  (Meursault)

description: At this stage, this wine is closed and packed with acidity. But just wait for a few years and the ripe wood and yellow fruits will emerge. It's a full-bodied, rich wine that needs to round out. Drink from 2016.
title: Joseph Faiveley 2011 Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This wine comes from one of the few white-wine vineyards in Vougeot. It is opulent and rich with creamed apple and ripe green plums. The fruit lies over the subtle wood aging that has smoothed the crisp texture. The wine is still young and will be best from 2021.
title: Domaine Bertagna 2015 Les Cras Premier Cru  (Vougeot)

description: This dense wine is still very young. The fruit still needs to express itself in a wine that is broad and ripe. Give this rich wine, with its creamy texture and touches of spice from wood aging, until 2021.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2015 Les Morgeots Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: White fruits, toast and balancing acidity give this wine both a great, crisp freshness and complexity. It is also a wine which could age well-five years or more.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2002 Vergennes  (Corton)

description: Young vines, planted in 2007, give a fresh, fruity wine with attractive citrus and zingy orange flavors. It is ripe and deliciously perfumed with a touch of minerality and saltiness. Drink from 2019.
title: Domaine Jacques Prieur 2014 Gréves Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: A huge, rich wine that exudes honey, spice and cream notes. The wood, though, is more subtle and is a satisfying  support to the fruit. Imported by USA Wine Imports.
title: Domaine Moillard 2003 Corton Charlemagne  (Corton-Charlemagne)

description: A rich, spicy, new wood-flavored wine from a unique parcel of white grapes next to the famed Clos de Vougeot. The wine is big, rich and densely flavored, packed with fresh apricots, and finishes with a hint of caramel. Imported by Boisset America.
title: Domaine de la Vougeraie 2003 Clos Blanc de Vougeot  (Vougeot)

description: Fresh toast and citrus aromas indicate a wine that is both full-bodied and balanced. The wood is very evident at this stage, giving a firm, toasty character. There are white peaches and citrus flavors, and long-lasting, refreshing acidity to finish.
title: Pierre Morey 2005 Premier Cru Perriéres  (Meursault)

description: Situated in the center of the premier crus of Puligny, Champgains produces an elegant, textured wine. This bottling, with the warmth of 2013 behind it, is fragrant with white fruits and has a soft aftertaste. It needs to age to bring it out its more complex character, so wait until 2018.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2013 Les Champgains Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: At this stage, this wine is fresh and lemony, but what lies beneath has huge power and richness and layers of toast and vanilla. Has great potential. Imported by Daniel Johnnes Wines.
title: Maison Champy 2003  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Fat and textured wine, pushing towards the tropical fruit end of the spectrum, with sweetness, pineapple and ripe peach flavors. It does have a mineral edge, with butter and toast undertones.
title: Domaine de la Pousse d'Or 2009 Le Cailleret Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: As with Clos de Vougeot in red, every producer needs a Corton-Charlemagne white. Aegerter's contribution is soft, honeyed and warm. It has hints of the concentration proper to this Grand Cru vineyard, allowing for a perfumed, ripe fruit character. It will develop quickly and will be ready to drink from 2017.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2013  Corton-Charlemagne

description: A modern, high toast style of wine, it packs spice and creamy vanilla flavors over rich, intense, green plum and ripe, sweet apples. The wood dominates to finish, but will balance out over the next 5 years.
title: Michel Picard 2002 Le Montrachet  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: One of a range of single-vineyard wines, this is tight and still very young. It has a chalky texture, feeling very mineral and nervy. The fruit hints at lemon and green plum, needing time to fill out. Drink from 2019.
title: Vignerons des Terres Secrétes 2014 Au Mont  (Saint-Véran)

description: Ripe and full, it has opulent peaches and apricots plus a light buttery character. Tangy with orange zest, it's full of flavor and has a generous feel at the end.
title: Collovray et Terrier 2012 Les Terres Noires  (Saint-Véran)

description: Big and rich, this complex wine punches above its appellation. It has rich fruits and a strong textured character, along with spice, vanilla and apple skin flavors. The structure is present and needs to develop. Drink from 2015.
title: Cave de Lugny 2012 Les Beluses  (Mâcon-Chardonnay)

description: A dense wine that is still young, this is full, textured and with plenty of both fruit and spice. A creamy vanilla character fills out this ripe wine and gives an extra dimension. Drink this rich wine from 2019.
title: Fabrice Larochette 2016 La Grande Bruyére  (Mâcon-Fuissé)

description: This well-proportioned wine has ripe fruits along with generous texture and acidity. A touch of wood gives extra weight. It's ready to drink, but will be even better by the end of 2014.
title: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2012 Au Brûlé  (Saint-Véran)

description: A wine that is broad, feeling full-bodied, with weight, pear and quince fruit flavors. The wine is attractively plump, toast and acidity adding richness. It opens slowly to give a rich aftertaste.
designation: Domaine des Deux Roches Rives de Longsault
title: Collovray et Terrier 2007 Domaine des Deux Roches Rives de Longsault  (Saint-Véran)

description: Attractively spicy as well as fruity, this is a ginger and apricot-flavored wine. Great acidity balances the warm fruitiness. Full in the mouth while also crisp, the wine is ready to drink.
title: Domaine des Valanges 2014 Les Cras  (Saint-Véran)

description: A delicate, crisp and lemon-flavored wine that comes from a small section of the Jura vineyard. It has a smooth texture, yellow and apple fruit flavors and some wood from barrel aging. It will develop into a rich and rounded wine, so it's best drunk from 2015.
title: Domaine Rolet Pére et Fils 2010 Chardonnay (L'Étoile)

description: Crisp, tight and mineral, this classic wine has citrus and apple fruits filled out with creamed pear. The zingy texture is still young and vibrant. With intense acidity at the end, the wine could still develop, so drink from early 2017.
title: Château Vitallis 2014  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: While this domaine is based in Chaintré it also has vines in Pouilly-Fuissé. This wine comes from a 2.4-acre vineyard on the clay and chalk soil that marks this appellation. It is rich, full in the mouth with a mineral texture and lively acidity. It is still young and will be better from late 2017.
title: Domaine Fabrice Larochette 2014 Les Robées  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This tangy, perfumed single-vineyard wine also has some ripe fruit. A zesty character dominates at this early stage, leaving room for richer yellow fruits to come through in time. The wine has good potential, so wait until 2017 to drink.
title: Jean Rijckaert 2014 Les Bouthiéres  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: A smooth and concentrated wine, very rich. Peach and nectarine fruits dominate, the acidity coming from a crisp citrus streak. The wine could benefit from another year in bottle to reveal its true intensity.
title: Domaine Thibert Pére et Fils 2008 Non Filtré  (Saint-Véran)

description: This is a beautiful, ripe wine, flavored with quince, pear and apricots. It is above all the zesty texture that gives this wine its character and attraction. Fruity, structured and likely to age well, the wine should be drunk from 2015.
title: Domaine Daniel Dugois 2012 Chardonnay (Arbois)

description: The wine is rich, full-bodied and creamy. Apricot, peach and pineapple flavors create an exotic feel. The balance is the acidity that keeps the wine structured and textured. It's a wine to age until 2016-2017.
title: Rijckaert 2011 Les Sarres Chardonnay (Cotes du Jura)

description: This mineral-textured wine is full of young fruit. Its acidity and crispness are refreshing now but they will fill out to give a tense, dense wine that has structure and depth of flavor. Give this wine some time and drink from 2019.
title: Domaine Pascal et Mireille Renaud 2017 Pascal Renaud Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Structured white fruits, this is a complex and concentrated wine. Toast, apple and apricot flavors are blended with herbs and intense acidity. Spice from the wood shows on the finish.
title: Labouré-Roi 2009 Premier Cru Réserve  (Montagny)

description: From vines situated close to the rock of Vergisson, this wine conveys a strong mineral character that is balanced by the apple and yellow flavors that are, in turn, cut by acidity. It's a tight, fragrant and crisp wine with aging potential. Drink from 2020.
title: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2016 Authentique  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: An impressive, textured wine, tight and mineral in character, this is also rich and has a great future, shown by its tangy acidity, steely edge and potential fruitiness. Dense and full bodied, it's likely to be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Fabrice Larochette 2015 Les Robées  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This is a crisp, textured wine, with tight acidity and a strong nervy character that will allow it to age. An edge of toastiness adds some complexity. Drink this attractive, fresh wine from 2019.
title: Vins Auvigue 2017 Moulin du Pont  (Saint-Véran)

description: This wine is full, rich and packed with yellow fruits. Spice and toastiness add to the complexity and attraction. It is a delicious, ripe wine with zesty acidity and a tight final texture.
title: Verget 2014 Vignes de Saint-Claude  (Saint-Véran)

description: Smoky and earthy, this is a wine that speaks of the ground in which it was grown, with intense mineral aromas a thick texture and a long, lime-tinged finish.
title: J. Moreau & Fils 2000 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Generous in style, with great freshness. The flavors are rich, touched by caramel, ripe white currants and some spice. A fine, red apple skin structure comes through to finish.
title: Jean-Marc Brocard 2005 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Sourced from the same three parcels each vintage, this is shot through with minerality and tight acidity. There is fruit behind this tension and that gives the wine both balance and also aging potential. Drink this complex wine from 2018.
designation: Closerie des Alisiers Trilogie de Terroirs
title: Maison Stéphane Brocard 2014 Closerie des Alisiers Trilogie de Terroirs  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: A short wood-aging has given this wine an extra dimension that's both ripe and ageworthy. Yellow fruits are spiced up by the toast and ginger flavors, whlle intense background acidity provides wonderful freshness. This wine deserves to age. Drink from 2017.
title: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2013 Quintessence  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: With light wood-aging flavors, this wine is both ripe and fresh. The touch of toast points up yellow fruits that are generous and rounded. Pineapple and peach are given an edge by the citrus acidity in the aftertaste. Drink from 2017. The family estate has been established since the 14th century.
title: Domaine Ninot 2014 La Barre  (Rully)

description: Fermented and aged in tank, the wine is nothing but simply attractive pure ripe fruit. It has density and concentration that come from the generous apple and yellow-fruit flavors. At the same time, the wine is cut by delicious acidity and minerality. Drink this wine from 2018.
title: Domaine Bégue-Mathiot 2014 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: On the right bank of the Serein river, Vaucoupin gives rich wines, showing its sunny exposition. This bottling is ripe, full in the mouth and intense with fragrant white fruits, vanilla and youthful acidity. With freshness still to the fore, it will age and will be better from 2017.
title: Domaine Céline et Frédéric Gueguen 2013 Vaucoupin Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This has a warm, rounded character, with pressing minerality. Notes of apple, pear and a touch of vanilla all add richness and an open character. It has warm, rich fruit on the finish.
title: Domaine Jean-Paul et Benoît Droin 2010 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Very tight wine, very mineral, with a distinct steel and coiled spring feel to it. Citrus and green apples dominate. This will age well.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2009 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: On the steely, taut side of Chablis, this is a wine for aging. It has fine complexity, lemon and green plum flavors vying with a buttery edge. Keep for 3-4 years.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2008 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: The toast character lends a firm structure to this solid, rich wine. A spice note pairs well with the white plum and apricot fruit, and there is a sense that this needs to age for several years in order to bring out its richness and full potential.
title: Domaine Faiveley 2010 Clos Rochette  (Mercurey)

description: Concentrated fruit from 75-year-old vines went into new oak for 23 months-and emerged barely showing it. There's great richness and minerality allied to pineapple and citrus flavors and a long, focused finish. Imported by Kermit Lynch.
title: Domaine Robert-Denogent 2002 La Croix  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This balanced wine, full of ripe fruits, also has good acidity and a crisp citrus edge. It conveys a warm character, the apricot freshened by lemon flavors and given a tangy aftertaste. Drink now.
title: Yves Giroux 2015 Les Raidillons  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: From vines aged between 40 and 80 years, this is a lightly wood-aged wine, with yellow fruits that go with the spicy toast. Full, ripe, and nicely cut with acidity, it has a creamy, smooth texture. Drink now.
title: Château Vitallis 2014 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Caramel aromas lead to a wine that is rich and full bodied. It has weight and concentration, along with fresh acidity that cuts through at the end. A good sense of minerality gives this wine extra texture. Drink from 2017.
title: Jean-Paul Paquet 2013 Domaine de Fussiacus  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This impressive wood-aged wine shows both the rich side of Pouilly Fuissé and its taut, minerally character. It is full and rich, yet always expressing a nervy, zingy edge. Age for at least three years.
title: Château Vitallis 2010 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: A rounded, soft wine that balances good ripe green and white fruits, fresh acidity and a light layer of wood. Finely made, worth aging.
title: Thibert Pére et Fils 2008  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: While this wine is ripe and generous, it also has a strong mineral edge as well as refreshing acidity. The blend of crispness and full yellow fruits give both balance and a delicious character to this attractive wine. Drink from late 2018.
title: Domaine Trouillet 2016  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: With richness from wood aging, this ripe, smooth and creamy wine is ready to drink. Citrus and yellow fruits contrast with the strong mineral texture typical of the appellation. It's a ripe wine, ready now and until 2024.
title: Domaine du Chalet Pouilly 2015  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: A beautifully ripe wine, this is textured and packed with fruit at the same time. It shows a classic mineral character of Pouilly-Fuissé along with generous yellow and citrus fruitiness. Produced by the Dutron family, who have been growers since the 19th century, this wine could age. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Vitallis 2016 Les Vignes du Château  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: There is a fine touch of spice in this wine. Bright and tangy, it is also full with white fruits, ripe acidity and a warm while zesty character. Still young and zesty, the wine will soften over the next few months into something more rounded. Drink from 2017.
title: Christophe Cordier 2014 En Faux  (Saint-Véran)

description: Crisp and steely, this is a bright and fruity wine. It has a tight texture cut with acidity and citrus flavors. The wine is lively, packed with fruitiness that has a delicious refreshing aftertaste. Drink from late 2017.
title: Etienne Boileau 2014 Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Situated in a side valley away from the main Serein river, this cool vineyard produces crisp, cool, stylish wines. This one is fresh and bright, all fruit without wood aging. Touches of melon back up the red-apple flavors. The aftertaste is still young, so this wine will be best from 2017.
title: Domaine Louis Moreau 2014 Vaulignot Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: The small Côte de Lechet Premier Cru is on the south side of the Serein valley. With its northerly exposure, it produces cool, structured wines, very crisp like this, with a delicious green character. Acidity and steeliness add to the texture.
title: La Chablisienne 2011 Côte de Lechet Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This wine is crisp, with a mineral texture that is tight and allows for considerable citric acidity. A riper background conveys rich apple flavors and a taut, nervy, steely character. Drink this concentrated wine from 2017.
title: Domaine Trouillet 2014  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: Full in the mouth, round and rich, the wine is finely structured, fresh and ripe at the same time. Delicious.
title: Daniel Barraud 2008 Alliance  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This is a rich wine from a rich year, giving it density as well as an opulent, ripe character, packed with apricots and white peaches. Acidity gives the wine crispness as well as a bright edge that contrasts with the intensity of the fruit and texture. Drink the wine from late 2018.
title: Camille Paquet 2015  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: The cool Côte de Lechet, facing north, produces a classically steely Chablis. This is still young, very tight and nervy, its acidity prominent even though the texture is ripe. Aging will bring balance between the crisp character and the richer green and white fruits. Drink from 2018.
title: La Chablisienne 2012 Côte de Lechet Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A finely rounded wine, with lovely ripe peach and pineapple fruits, lifted by a dash of lemon juice. Finely balanced, ripe in character, although always textured and tangy. There is a mouthwatering finish.
title: La Chablisienne 2008 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This ripe and full wine has hints of toast and baked bread along with rich apricot and peach flavors. The texture is warm while the aromatic aftertaste is immediately attractive.
title: Marcel Couturier 2014 Le Clos Reyssie  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This is a ripe, rounded and aromatic wine, with just the right stretch of minerality and juicy citrus flavor. Crisp, tangy and refreshing in its fruitiness, the wine is rich and full, finishing with a final burst acidity.
title: Domaine Fourrey 2014 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: The warm Beauroy vineyard has produced a rich, full-bodied and concentrated wine. It has a ripe structure that's cut with mineral notes, honey and apple and pear flavors. The wine is still developing and needs to age. Drink from 2017.
title: Pascal Bouchard 2012 Beauroy Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Totally fresh, this is crisp and packed with citrus. A complex, tight texture brings out nervy acidity, a strongly mineral character and a firm structure. Age this youthful wine and drink from 2018.
title: Pascal Bouchard 2013 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Open, generous and packed with butter and honey. Yellow fruits are the dominant character, touched with toast and ripeness. This is an opulent and full wine.
title: La Chablisienne 2005 Mont-de-Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Fresh and fruity, this wine has a crisp, mineral character that gives an intense texture. It is balanced, ripe while still taut and crisp. The background to this is riper yellow fruits and a full, generous aftertaste. Drink from 2016.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2013 Les Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Rounded with a good texture, this is a wine that has a good future. It has weight, fruit that is fresh and well wooded showing plenty of spice and bright acidity.
title: Pierre Vessigaud 2008 Vers Pouilly  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This cool wine is typical of one of the more structured of the premier cru vineyards, enhancing the mineral character and tight green-fruit acidity. The balance comes from a touch of spice and hazelnut flavors. Drink the wine from 2020.
title: Domaine Fourrey 2017 Côte de Lechet Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Full and rich, this generous wine comes from one of the sunniest Premier Crus in Chablis. It offers warmth, ripe white fruits and lime flavors along with a spicy texture. The wine's richness is already enjoyable but it will be better from 2020.
title: Domaine Fourrey 2017 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Soft and full-bodied, this offers bright apple and citrus fruits layered with toast from wood aging. Under the broad exterior, the wine is developing more tangy, zesty fruits and a tight texture. It needs to age to bring everything together. Drink from 2017.
title: La Chablisienne 2012 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This exudes notes of ripe yellow fruits while keeping an edge of structure. It's fragrant, with a fine dense texture that brings out acidity and a caramel flavor. It has aging potential, so keep it for over three years.
title: La Chablisienne 2010 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A rich style of Chablis, full of ripe apricot, plum and pear juice flavors. There is a buttery character as well that rounds the wine out while still leaving a tense core, hinting at minerality.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2008 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Tight, taut steely in character, this tastes of its great chalk terroir. It has delicious layered crispness, green and fresh red apples, finished with a powerful citrus element. Without doubt, a wine for aging.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2007 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This finely structured wine shows spice, almonds and delicious green plum fruits. There is some wood here, but the fruit is a great, dominating burst of ripeness. The finish lingers with fresh acidity. Worth aging for 2-3 years.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2006 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Great steely, mineral wine, powered by startlingly fresh green fruits, vibrant, vivid acidity and delicious herb and plum flavors. This is lively, but also densely packed with flavor.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2006 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Concentrated, dense, powerful and full of glistening green fruits, this wine is lightly touched with caramel, but more dominated by ripe acidity. The aftertaste is tight, suggesting good aging potential.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2005 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: With its straw color and wood aging aromas, this is rich, bearing yellow peach and pear fruits, along with a toast note and juicy acidity. It's already impressive but should drink well for another three years at least.
title: Domaines Devillard 2010 Château de Chamirey  (Mercurey)

description: This rich wine is full of young fruits that have a spicy edge from wood aging. The floral aroma is enhanced on the palate by almonds, acidity and ripe green-plum flavors. A ripe wine, it will be ready to drink from 2020.
title: Vignerons de Buxy 2016 Les Chaniots Premier Cru  (Montagny)

description: The great fruit produces a delicious wine that is also structured with a strong steely element. It is full of yellow fruits, layers of wood and juicy acidity. The aftertaste is as bright as a button.
title: Trenel Fils 2012  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: From granite soil, this rounded wine has a firm core of structure. Pineapple and peach fruit flavors surround this center, making it full in the mouth, rich and charming. Acidity at the end and the firm texture promise some aging. Drink from 2015.
title: Château des Rontets 2011 Pierrefolle  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Rich, creamy wood-aged wine that shows pear, apple and toast flavors ane even a hint of honey. Smooth and textured, it has fine final spice and acidity to add further interest.
title: Domaine du Chalet Pouilly 2009 Eléve en Fûts de Chêne  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: There is a fine mineral-driven backbone to this ripe, concentrated and fruity wine, which gives its dense apricot and pineapple flavors great structure. It needs to age for at least four years.
designation: Château de Rully Saint Jacques Cuvée R. de Ternay
title: Antonin Rodet 2010 Château de Rully Saint Jacques Cuvée R. de Ternay  (Rully)

description: This is a beautiful, bright wine, still very young although already hinting at the warmth of Fourchaume. The steely texture is right up front, along with crisp apple and citrus fruits. Underneath, a vanilla, toasty character shows promise for aging. Drink from 2017.
title: Domaine Vrignaud 2013 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A toasty and buttery wine that is initially smooth and silky. It's only on the mid-palate that the tauter, more steely character of Chablis comes through. With fresh acidity, this easily combines both ripeness and mouthwatering crispness.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2008 Domaine Drouhin-Vaudon Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: An impressively full wine, its ripe apricot flavors melding seamlessly into rich wood and concentrated flavors. The lemon acidity enlivens the ripe yellow fruits, leaving a rich final impression.
title: Domaine Leflaive 2008  Mâcon-Verze

description: A steely wine, it's tight with acidity and apple fruit flavors. It has a brighter, crisper side, but the wine is still nervy and textured. Acidity at the end means it can age. Drink from 2016.
title: Manuel Seguin 2012 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: A selection of wines from 30 different parcels, this rich, smooth, open wine wears its toast well, the caramel and vanilla flavors melding easily with apricots, melon and finishing with acidity. The aftertaste continues this marriage of flavors.
title: Château de Fuissé 2006 Tête de Cru  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Full bodied, rich and ripe, this wine has a minerally texture and is loaded with tropical fruit, citrus and apricot flavors. It's a serious selection that needs some aging. This is one of a series of single-vineyard wines from the Comte de Ternay estate.
designation: Château de Rully La Bressande Cuvée Comte R. de Ternay Premier Cru
title: Antonin Rodet 2010 Château de Rully La Bressande Cuvée Comte R. de Ternay Premier Cru  (Rully)

description: Flint and peach aromas give a wine that is steely as well as boasting flowery fruits, bright pears and acidity along with a structured, mineral feel.
title: Domaine Marc Roy 2011 Les Champs Perdrix  (Marsannay)

description: This smooth wine is rich with yellow fruits, an opulent texture and a sprinkling of spice. The acidity and the crisper citrus flavors in the background give the essential lift to this ripe wine. Drink now.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2015 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Ripe and soft, with a texture that is well balanced, this wine has peach and apricot flavors marrying well with the layers of wood. There is a strong, fresh element to give the wine a final lift.
title: Roger Lassarat 2008 Clos de France  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: The steely character of a young Chablis is very apparent in this wine. It is crisp, lemon flavored and with a mineral edge. The wine has a juicy freshness, still young at heart and needing to age. Drink from 2018.
title: Louis Max 2014 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: The wine is tight and closed, hiding its natural fruitiness. For the moment, what is showing is acidity and a strongly mineral texture. This complex wine needs aging to fill out the structure. Drink from 2017.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2012 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A toasty, smoky element to this concentrated wine balances with the rich apricot fruit and the mineral texture. Acidity and a citrus line cut through the generous, full flavors. The aftertaste shows the wine is still young. Wait to drink until 2017.
title: Rijckaert 2014 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Ripe, rich and fruity, this honeyed wine is generous and succulent at the same time. The 75-year-old vines delivered a great success, combining good texture with rich fruit and acidity. Drink now.
title: Clos des Rocs 2016 En Chantonne  (Pouilly-Loché)

description: A selection from different parcels in the Château de Fuissé vineyard, this is a rich wine, initially soft, then showing a more textured character. It has weight, concentration, the wood adding another dimension to an already complex wine.
title: Château de Fuissé 2009 Tête de Cru  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This wine has spice, concentrated yellow fruits and a delicious backbone of acidity. With its acidity firmly in place, the wine is beginning to reveal the richer yellow fruit and tangy lemon. Already delicious, it will be better from 2017.
title: Domaine de la Croix Senaillet 2014  Saint-Véran

description: This rich, soft wine is very approachable. A honeyed edge balances the crisp texture and ripe apples. The wine comes from one of the more northerly of the premier crus, but it has a southerly expression that gives the warm fruit in this wine. Drink from 2020.
title: Domaine Cheneviéres 2016 L'Homme Mort Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Now mature, this ripe wine has a creamy texture that is cut with the steely acidity of Chablis. Yellow fruits and a bright aftertaste keep this wine in the fruity stage. The aftertaste, though, has a more leafy character that shows its maturity. Drink now.
title: Domaine Philippe Goulley 2010 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: On the south side of the village of Chablis, the Vaillons vineyard is on the cool, left bank of the river Serein. It is fruity with a creamy texture and a line of steely acidity that often marks out the premier crus, giving this wine the chance to age. Drink from 2017.
title: Domaine Louis Moreau 2014 Les Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Ripe and creamy in apple and pear fruitiness, this is cut by just the right amount of acidity. It's balanced, with fruit and and bright steeliness working well together. Drink from 2016.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2012 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Closed in character, it has power and density as well as the potential of great fruitiness. A creamy texture with a rich feel offers suggestions of yellow fruits as well as apple. Drink from 2016.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2011 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: "L'Homme Mort," which is French for "the dead man," is a small section of the Fourchaume Premier Cru, and it is a signature wine of Jean Durup's Château de Maligny. It's opulent, ripe and rounded, with a full, fruity character and toast flavor. On the finish, there is an edge of grapefruit acidity. Age for 3-4 years.
title: Château de Maligny 2010 L'Homme Mort Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Round and rich, this has streaks of lemon and orange zest that cut through the vanilla and creamed apple texture. A note of spice makes the wine complex and rich. This is worth aging for several years.
title: Château de Maligny 2010 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A rich style of Chablis, with a toasty quality and yellow fruits mixed with acidity. The wine is open and round, full in the mouth, with concentrated ripe fruit and a soft texture. It should easily age for 2-3 years, but it is delicious now.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2009 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: In a crisp style, this has lively white fruit flavors, a youthful, steely mineral character, balanced by caramel richness and fine refreshing acidity. Age for 2-3 years.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2007 Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A round style of Chablis, rich in toast and yellow fruits, this is densely concentrated, the flavors going deep into the glass. The acidity brings everything together, a crisp framework of apple juice and green berries.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2007 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Lightly honeyed, this citrus-flavored wine comes a vineyard southeast of Chablis. It is all fruit although strong mineral texture gives it shape as well as sustaining the lemon acidity. Drink this wine from late 2018.
title: Domaine Gueguen 2016 Vosgros Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Crisp, with green plum flavors, this shows plenty of immediate freshness, very open. The structure is soft, with creaminess and toast, the hints of minerality and austerity initially kept at arms length, then gradually pushing forward into the delicious finale.
title: William Févre 2006 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This northeast-facing vineyard produces wines with a cool edge like this pure, intensely fruity bottling. It has a directness that is enhanced by wood aging to give a tightly textured wine that will need some time. Drink from 2020.
title: Château de Chamilly 2016 Les Jardins Premier Cru  (Montagny)

description: From a small vineyard of less than two acres, this wine has pure, ripe fruit, gentle acidity and some tangy minerality. It is ripe with apricots as well as citrus, offering acidity and vanilla from wood aging. Drink this smooth and opulent wine from 2020.
title: Château de Chamilly 2015 Les Jardins Premier Cru  (Montagny)

description: Only a small portion of this vineyard is planted with Chardonnay, and it has produced a minerally wine that's both crisp and ripe. The acidity is dominant at this stage, which lends the palate a juicy, peach- and citrus-like character. This wood-aged selection needs time.
designation: Clos de la Croix de Pierre
title: Louis Jadot 2010 Clos de la Croix de Pierre  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: This perfumed wine offers good balance between citrus and warmer fruits. Peach and apple come together easily with the lemon flavors. The wine has a bright, tight mineral edge and is ready to drink.
title: Domaine Gilles Morat 2014 Domaine Chataigneraie-Laborier Sur la Roche  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This is a ripe and smoothly textured wine. It is already finely balanced, rich with toast, apricot fruits and a tight, mineral character. It is enjoyable now but will age well until 2022.
title: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2012 Quintessence  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This wine combines spice from wood aging with the crispest sliced-apple flavors. A touch of honey enhances the wine's richness and balances the final toastiness. From a vineyard next to Chassagne-Montrachet, this wine will develop further and should be ready from 2019.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2014 Pitangerets Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: Concentrated and rich, with some wood influence, this has ripe yellow fruits that are balanced with an intense streak of acidity, lending a sense of tension. It's very full, round and already a delight to drink.
title: Jean-Claude Boisset 2009 En Remilly Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: Peach and apricot flavors dominate this ripe, full-bodied wine that has plenty of acidity to back up the richness. Still developing, it will emerge as a ripe, concentrated wine that will be generous and full. Drink from 2017.
title: Jean-Christophe Perraud 2014  Saint-Véran

description: Full, balanced, with a touch of spice and vanilla, this is a well-made wine. It has sophistication from the tastiness as well as a tight, fresh side from the lime and Rocha pear flavors. It could age a few more months, so drink from 2016.
title: Christophe Cordier 2013 En Faux  (Saint-Véran)

description: Rounded, rich and warm, it has excellent acidity along with touches of wood and very pure citrus flavors. Peach fruits give a riper feel. Drink now, but better to wait until 2015.
title: Benjamin Leroux 2011  Auxey-Duresses

description: Full, rounded wine starring creamed apples and pink grapefruit acidity. The wine is crisp, fresh, with a firm texture and lively acidity.
title: Domaine Cordier 2008 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: From old vines, some more than 80 years in age, this wine is aromatic and intense, with generous yellow fruits. The fresher side of the wine comes from the tangy texture and good acidity. A dense wine, it has a ripe feel that is letting it age. Drink from 2020.
title: Cave de Viré 2016 Quintaine  (Viré-Clessé)

description: This producer does not believe in much oak aging (in this case 3%), but even that small amount brings out richness while leaving the delicious fruit right in place. From one of the top, ripe premier crus in Chablis, this wine is rich, creamy while never losing the proper tang of citrus and bright acidity. Drink from 2019.
title: Domaine Besson 2015 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Opulent, ripe and fruity, this is classic Saint-Aubin. Generous fruitiness is balanced with crisp acidity and touches of minerality and spicy wood. Its fruitiness makes it accessible now, but several years' aging will make it even better and certainly more complex.
title: Jean-Claude Boisset 2011 Sur Gamay Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: It's obvious that Pernand-Vergelesses can produce great Chardonnay since part of the Corton-Charlemagne Grand Cru is in the village. This is a cool wine, crisp with textured acidity and age-worthy acidity and toast. The wine is taut, spicy and moves strongly in the citrus direction. Lime and tangerine flavors are strong along with a complex mineral structure. Drink from 2019.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2014  Pernand-Vergelesses

description: This is a youthful, fruity wine with crisp yellow-fruit and citrus flavors, with a toastiness from wood aging. Sourced from Saint-Aubin, it has a cool, fresh feel that complements its pristine fruitiness. It's for drinking soon, but will also improve with age through 2021.
title: Jean-Claude Boisset 2011 En Remilly Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: Ripe, smooth and deliciously rounded, this is a generous wine. Spice and yellow fruits are right up front, supported by just enough acidity. The wine is rich and ready to drink.
title: Rijckaert 2015 Vers Chanes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This wine is ripe, with good balance between acidity and the rich yellow fruits. It has a lightly tangy character, although it is more about delicious juiciness and a warm, generous character that is lightly sustained by toast. Drink from 2017.
title: Domaine de la Croix Senaillet 2013  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: There are only a few white wines made in Beaune, coming from small parcels dotted across the appellation. This open, rich 18-month wood-aged wine is generous and ripe with creamed apple and spiced pear. It's a toasty wine that retained its fruit. Drink from 2020.
title: Louis Jadot 2015  Beaune

description: Deceptively light in weight, this elegant wine features a delicate filigree of spice and mineral entwined around a core of apples and pears. Traces of cinnamon and crushed stone add complexity to the long finish.
title: J. Moreau & Fils 2000 Bougros  (Chablis)

description: Showy aromas of vanilla cream, almond and ripe peach blend in flavors of oranges and tangerines in the mouth. This medium-weight wine finishes gently, with soft underpinnings of toasted nuts and chalk. The best Joyau of the trio.
title: J. Moreau & Fils 2000 Cuvée Joyau Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A big, forceful, buttery wine that boasts loads of slippery river stones, along with spicy clove notes. Full-bodied and very ripe, showing more mineral than fruit, this grand cru should be approachable in 2-3 years and last up to 10.
title: J. Moreau & Fils 1999 Les Clos  (Chablis)

description: Ripe, full and showing the richness of the vintage, this comes from one of the premier crus vineyards on the south bank of the Serein river. It's crisp with strong minerality, while also having plenty of ripe citrus and apple fruit. Drink from 2019.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2015 Vaillon Premier Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: L'Homme Mort is a northern extension of the Fourchaume Premier Cru vineyard, so called because this was where a local lord dispensed justice by death. It often produces cooler wines such as this. It is tight, with toasted bread hints and with a strongly tangy character. It does need to develop and shouldn't be drunk before 2018.
title: Domaine Cheneviéres 2014 L'Homme Mort Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: There are touches of toast here, allowing the wine to broaden and become riper. It's still young, showing a future of yellow fruits contrasting with a tight and nervy texture. The aftertaste is full, ripe and generous. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Ellevin 2013 Vosgros Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: While this wine has the crispness of Chablis, it also has weight and concentration. The bright green-apple flavor is underpinned by a sense of minerality. Nervy, tense yet fruity, this can age for 2-3 years.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2010 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This is a rich, rounded and concentrated wine. Good structure comes both from the wood aging and from the acidity of the apple and apricot fruits. Developing slowly, it will become an impressive, ripe wine. Drink from 2018. The grapes come from the highest vineyard in Chassagne, just under the woods.
title: Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2012 En PImont  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: More steely than some Meursault, this layers wood and mineral flavors with a fine structure and tastes of apple skins and nutmeg. This wine could age 3-4 years, but it is already delicious.
title: Domaine René Monnier 2004 Les Chevaliéres  (Meursault)

description: There is a fine balance here between wood and deliciously rich fruit. It gives a ripe wine that fills the glass with spice, apricots and a crisp citrus zest. The wine glows ripely to the finish.
title: Faiveley 2007 Blagny Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: While this wine demonstrates the telltale cool element of the appellation, it also offers ripe fruit, pear and peach flavors lightly layered with wood. The wine is crisp at the end, with a mineral aftertaste. Drink from 2016.
title: Louis Latour 2011 Caradeux Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: This is already a delicious wine. Young, fragrant fruits bring acidity and a dense sense of structure. The aftertaste shows the spice from wood aging.
title: Domaine Luc et Lise Pavelot 2011 Sous Frétille Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: This opulent wine is held in check by a strong mineral streak. It is still a little young but its yellow fruits, touches of mango and crisper kiwi are all delicious. Give this wine until 2019 to drink.
title: Ernest Merguey-Perron 2016  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: Here's true "old vine" wine-from vines 75 years old on average-and it is ripe and toasty, with flavors of almonds, spice and baked bread. Fresh, crisp apples and green plums are lifted by a citrus aftertaste. Drink this attractive wine now.
title: Pierre Merguey 2014 Vielles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Steely and mineral, this wine is as crisp and chalky-textured as possible. It is tight, with nervy acidity as well as touches of wood. A more buttery, rounded character is just beginning to show through to fill out the texture.
title: Denis Jeandeau 2012 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: The most southerly of the Saint-Aubin vineyards, this touches both Puligny-Montrachet and Chassagne-Montrachet. While it doesn't have the extreme finesse of either of these communes, this wine has plenty of the richness and the style. Its balance is impeccable, with acidity, toast and white fruits coming together well. Drink this wine from 2020.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2015 En Remilly Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: Although the oak imprints strong flavors in this wine, it's still young, so all the spice and toastiness will integrate. The fruit is there, showing a rich medley of apples, pears and citrus. As it matures, the texture will flesh out to result in a generous wine with a promising future. Drink from 2020.
title: Domaine Jessiaume 2015 Les Graviéres Premier Cru  (Santenay)

description: There is a touch of wood here, partnering with the wine's weight, minerality and crisp character. White fruit flavors of apple and pear lend further brightness.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2010  Meursault

description: A beautifully ripe and rounded wood-aged wine. It brings out all the opulence of Meursault while keeping a tight, textured element as counterpoint. The wood flavors are beginning to blend into the lychee and peach flavors, promising an even richer experience in a few months.
title: Vincent Sauvestre 2009 Clos des Tessons  (Meursault)

description: A full, ripe wine, this is rich in white fruits, but balanced by bright acidity. Produced in a vineyard close to Buxy, it has a taut edge, plenty of honey and lemon flavors, and a touch of toast. It's developing well, and should be ready from 2020.
title: Laurent Cognard 2016 Les Bassets Premier Cru  (Montagny)

description: The fruit here is attractive, pears and white currants on top of pink grapefruit and orange zest. It shows its structure and its tense minerality only slowly, allowing the acidity to give it a lift and vibrancy. This is a wine that is still young, still smoothing out its hard edges.
designation: Domaine Long-Depaquit Les Vaucopins Premier Cru
title: Albert Bichot 2006 Domaine Long-Depaquit Les Vaucopins Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Wood spice flavors still dominate this zingy, mineral-textured wine. As it ages, it will reveal more rich fruit flavors of ripe apricot and pineapple. The acidity balances the wine's fruitiness. Keep for 2-3 years.
designation: Château de Chamirey La Mission Premier Cru
title: Domaines Devillard 2009 Château de Chamirey La Mission Premier Cru  (Mercurey)

description: Rich-smelling, with hints of talc punctuating ripe pear aromas. Honeyed pears and apples glide across the palate, finishing with flourishes of anise and minerals.
designation: Les Vaillons Premier Cru Vieilles Vignes
title: Domaine Laroche 2002 Les Vaillons Premier Cru Vieilles Vignes  (Chablis)

description: This wine has the richness of 2009, while still is mineral, taut and textured. The yellow fruits are balanced by intense acidity and a ripe, full-bodied feel. The wine is complex, needing aging; the aftertaste intense, crisp and fruity.
title: Garnier et Fils 2009 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Blagny is a small hamlet just up the hill from Les Perriéres. This is a cooler spot, and the wine shows this with its structure and flavors of fresh green fruits over generous portions of wood. A wine that should age for more than 5 years.
designation: Château de Blagny Meursault Blagny Premier Cru
title: Louis Latour 2004 Château de Blagny Meursault Blagny Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This wine has a zesty structure, with good minerality and ripe yellow fruits.Tightly structured with acidity, it comes from one of the cooler villages of the Côte de Beaune and shows a lively, bright aftertaste. Drink from 2018.
title: Louis Latour 2015 En Caradeux Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: Grapefruit, toast and white peach aromas give this wine a great start. It is not powerful but is deliciously balanced with fresh green plum and pink grapefruit flavors rounded out with just the perfect amount of wood. Drink 2010.
title: Morey-Blanc 2005 Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: Full and buttery, as befits a Meursault, the wine also has a fine-textured acidity, spice and toast. It is rich, although with a crisp citrus edge that balances out the ripe melon and honey flavor. Ready to drink, but could age for a few years.
title: Labouré-Roi 2008 Les Chevaliers  (Meursault)

description: There is already a fine balance between the ripe yellow fruits and juicy acidity. Together with the toast from wood aging, they make a rich, well textured wine that has excellent potential. Drink this finely structured wine from 2016.
title: Château des Rontets 2012 Les Birbettes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: From old vines planted in 1955, this dense, impressive wine offers both perfume apple and pear fruits and a creamy texture. Behind this generous front, the wine is tight, steely and needs to age. Give it until 2018.
title: Domaine Vrignaud 2013 Fourchaume Premier Cru Vieilles Vignes  (Chablis)
