description: Smooth, ripe and rich, this wine offers flavors of white fruit and apricot balanced by tangy acidity. It's full in weight and developing fast; drink from 2019.
title: Domaine de Suremain 2016 En Sazenay Premier Cru  (Mercurey)

description: This premier-cru vineyard, wholly owned by the Devillard family, has produced a broad, ripe wine. It is generous, somewhat muted at this stage although promising plenty of citrus and yellow fruits and acidity as it ages. The wood aging creates a smooth hint at the back. Drink from 2021.
designation: Château de Chamirey La Mission Premier Cru
title: Domaines Devillard 2015 Château de Chamirey La Mission Premier Cru  (Mercurey)

description: Pale gold colored wine with a soft texture, light wood touches and ripe yellow fruits. The wine is rich, warm, opulent in character, open and fruity. A touch of texture brings out the acidity at the end.
designation: Château de Chamirey La Mission Premier Cru
title: Domaines Devillard 2011 Château de Chamirey La Mission Premier Cru  (Mercurey)

description: With a touch of spice from the wood, this wine is full of yellow and apple fruits yet with a cool thread of acidity. It is a lively, bright wine, filled out with fruitiness. Drink from 2017.
title: Louis Latour 2014 En Caradeux Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: This full-bodied, rich wine is open and ripe. Delicious layers of yellow fruits are sustained by the mineral texture and crisp acidity. Although this wine is good to drink now, it will be much better if aged further, so wait until late 2018.
title: Domaine Sophie Cinier 2016 Collection  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Striking a great balance between elegance and richness, this shows plenty of sweet fruit, white peaches and quince, while also keeping poise with  its structure and finishing acidity. This will be a great food Chardonnay.
title: Henri de Villamont 2005 Sous le Puits Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: A parcel of nine acres in this village vineyard has produced a generous, wood-aged wine. While it is still young, one can easily discern the wine's elegance, white-fruit flavors, acidity and its potential. Fresh now, this wine will be even better from 2021.
title: Château de Santenay 2016 En Vesvau  (Saint-Aubin)

description: The appellation is increasingly noted for its rich and generous white wines, like this bottling. This wood-aged wine is ripe with apples and peaches and fragrant with a squeeze of lime juice. It is balanced, full of acidity and rich fruit finished with a light toast. Drink from 2018.
title: Château de Santenay 2014 En Vesvau  (Saint-Aubin)

description: Saint-Aubin, in a valley leading up into the hills from the Côte de Beaune, is well known for its white wines. This wine is structured and textured with a tight minerality. As a contrast, the wood aging adds creamy and vanilla flavors, giving the wine some richness. Drink from 2017.
title: Alex Gambal 2013 Dent aux Chiens Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: A great swathe of rich, well-defined fruit and a complex texture of pear and apple skins along with the freshest grapefruit and citrus character. This is an intense wine, the fruit fully in focus.
designation: Domaine la Soufrandiére Climat les Quarts
title: Bret Brothers 2008 Domaine la Soufrandiére Climat les Quarts  (Saint-Véran)

description: This wine comes from a single vineyard site on a south/south-east facing slope. It is rich in everything that a Saint-Véran should have: ripe fruit, balanced acidity and a generous full texture. With acidity to match, this is developing into a fine wine. Drink from late 2018.
title: Domaine des Valanges 2015 Les Terres Noires  (Saint-Véran)

description: This wine is tight, nervy and crisp, with a strongly mineral texture. There is good acidity, crisp and textured. Apples and citrus dominate this structured wine. Drink from 2019.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2013 Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: From old vines, this rich and concentrated wine is dominated by ripe apple and pear flavors. They combine with the well-judged toastiness from wood aging to give a full, dense wine will age well. Drink from 2018.
designation: Les Vaillons Vieilles Vignes Premier Cru
title: Domaine Laroche 2013 Les Vaillons Vieilles Vignes Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Aged for 30 months in wood, this Chablis has a distinctively ripe and rich character that puts it closer to Meursault in style. Only on the finish, through all of the toast and fruit flavors, does the steely acidity emerge.
title: Garnier et Fils 2008 Grains Dorées  (Chablis)

description: With that extra concentration that comes from low-yielding old vines, this has great depth of flavor. It has an apple flavor and crisp, citrusy acidity as well as a more toasty character. Complex and certainly ageworthy, this should keep for at least five years.
designation: Les Vieilles Vignes Montmains Premier Cru
title: Pascal Bouchard 2010 Les Vieilles Vignes Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A steely, mineral wine, concentrated and firm, with vibrant green fruits and very fresh acidity. The structure circles around green apple skins, with tangerine zest and some dry tannins. This is a wine that should be aged-give it 2-3 years. Screwcap.
designation: Les Fourchaumes Vieilles Vignes Premier Cru
title: Domaine Laroche 2006 Les Fourchaumes Vieilles Vignes Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: The elegant, forward nose of this estate bottling boasts Asian spice, pear and acacia-blossom aromas. It's very structured and tight now on the palate, with ripe earthy fruit, anise and hay notes still coming together. Really kicks into gear on the long, expansive finish, which is at once juicy and minerally. Impressive now and better in two years. Drink 2003-2008.
title: Olivier Leflaive 1998 Abbaye de Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Very mineral in style, this is a structured, textured wine with good aging potential. It's acidity, still pronounced and up front, reveals itself with crisp citrus flavors that accent warm yellow fruits. The wine needs a year or two before drinking, so wait until 2015.
title: Henri de Villamont 2010  Puligny-Montrachet

description: Crisp and fruity, but also with some weight, this dense, textured wine has a very minerally character, with a straight line of tight acidity. This is complex and tense while also refreshing.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2010 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A rounded wine, although still young. It has ripe fruit, creamed apples and fresh acidity. The wood flavors give an extra smoothness as well as a more complex long-lasting finish.
title: Domaine Emmanuel Giboulot 2009 La Grand Chatelaine  (Côte de Beaune)

description: Full-throttle Meursault, with intense flavors of peach, pear and pineapple wrapped in a thick layer of dried spices and toast. The mouthfeel is rich and unctuous, the finish long and spicy. Try now-2008.
title: Domaine Jacques Prieur 2001 Clos de Mazeray  (Meursault)

description: This wine is rounded, rich and full of ripe fruit. Its wood flavors, giving spice and vanilla, are a backdrop to the generous apricot and pear flavors and good acidity. Drink this wine from 2022.
title: Domaine Faiveley 2015 Sous Blagny Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: The chalky soil conveys a cool feeling to this wine. Tight and mineral, it has yellow fruits that show good acidity. Toasty wood gives a juicy aftertaste. It's already delicious, but the wine's cool character will develop further, so drink from 2016.
title: Domaine Chanson 2011 Les Caradeux Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: A single-parcel wine, this offers great minerality and fruit. Nutmeg, ripe apples and juicy apricots are balanced by the tight mineral texture of this concentrated wine. Its fruitiness is up front, ebullient and refreshing. Drink from 2019.
title: Domaine Pascal et Mireille Renaud 2016 Pascal Renaud Aux Chailloux  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Made from fruit that was sourced from a 2.4-acre plot on the steep slopes of Vergisson, this is an intense, ripe, wood-aged wine. The acidity is allied to the spice and yellow fruit flavors. A concentrated wine of great purity, this is worth aging for several years.
title: Domaine Ferret 2010 Tête de Cru Les Perriéres  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Open and flattering, as are many of the 2000s, showing a dose of smoky, toasty oak layered over buttered nuts, honey and peach. Turns more citrusy on the finish, with tangerine and mineral notes lingering gently. Quite oaky, but has the depth of fruit to support it.
title: Louis Latour 2000 Le Referts  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Fruity and rounded, this has attractive, citrus-like acidity that cuts through the caramel and apricot flavors. There is a delicious, forward orange-juice flavor that adds to the fresh feel of the wine. It's ready to drink, although it will also age.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2010 Sentier du Clou Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: Made from grapes sourced from vines that were planted in 1955, this is ripe and rich. The fruit is still reticent, but it will develop into a concentrated, full-bodied wine. Its density is balanced by a firm, minerally structure. Age this for 2-3 years.
title: Domaine Vrignaud 2010 Vieilles Vignes Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Leflaive owns a small parcel of vines in the Clos Saint-Marc and also buys grapes from neighbors. The wine is ripe, but still has restraint, with flavors of green plums and a touch of spice. A firm structure promises aging, and there's a delicious fresh zing to the finish.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2004 Clos Saint-Marc Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This is very structured and full, with a powerful minerality, citrus and spice flavors, and a tight, nervy character. It has the weight to age for 3-4 years.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2010  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: Tight, mineral and balanced, this a perfumed, fragrant and crisply fruity wine. With its bright acidity, touch of toast and nervy aftertaste, the wine is not quite ready. It comes from an east-facing vineyard across a small valley from the Corton-Charlemagne Grand Cru. Drink from 2017.
designation: Creux de la Net Premier Cru
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2014 Creux de la Net Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: This ripe wine comes from vines from two parcels: one normally in the wine, with vines more than more than 60-years-old, the other a hilltop vineyard added in 2014. It is full of rich white fruits that skirt on the zesty side of citrus, giving a crisp edge to this otherwise full wine. It is balanced, juicy and ready to drink.
title: Bret Brothers 2014 Climat Les Clos Reyssié  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Balanced, soft wine, keeping its freshness and acidity, rounding it out with some wood and pear juice flavors. A fine, classic wine.
title: Château de Fuissé 2008 Les Combettes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Obviously toasty, this spicy wine also has plenty of crisp fruit to balance its richness. It is now mature, ripe with white fruits, citrus and a tight texture that gives it final freshness. Drink now.
title: Domaine Saint Marc 2015 Bois de Blagny  (Meursault)

description: This normally rich Meursault has gone into overdrive in 2009, producing a superopulent wine. It does, however, balance that with fine acidity and a mineral edge. It opens slowly to give its apple and peach fruits.
title: Roux Pére et Fils 2009 Clos des Poruzots Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This is the top Cuvée from Pouilly-Fuissé's most famous estate. It is a big, round wine, its curves opulent and generous. There are yellow fruits, particularly apricots, and the wine is given some sinew by its acidity and by the light spice aftertaste.
title: Château de Fuissé 2006 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Warm, rich, with a southern Chardonnay ripeness, this shows high toast, but also ripe tropical fruit. The acidity is light, with a creamy texture, and added spice and richness. It's a harmonious style that needs 3-4 years.
title: Château de Fuissé 2006 Le Clos  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This was the first vineyard bought by the Bouchard family, purchased in 1791. More than 220 years later, this 2011 has a delicate touch of wood nestled in the heart of creamy fruit flavors. Crisp lemon and tight acidity give a bright, fresh aftertaste. Drink from 2016.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2011 Clos Saint-Landry Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: Fragrant and generous, this ripe wine shows its fruitiness as easily as it reveals its structure. Its ripe, full-bodied character remains tightly textured, which makes it an age-worthy selection.
title: Garnier et Fils 2010 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This is the second wine from the Château Grenouilles vineyard, very fresh, but at the same time weighty and concentrated, with wood, caramel and generous fruits. Age for 5 years.
designation: Les Fiefs de Grenouilles Grand Cru
title: La Chablisienne 2005 Les Fiefs de Grenouilles Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Initially smooth and rounded, this wine opens to reveal a structured character. A note of tangy lemon zest cuts through the pear and quince flavors, which creates a balance between richness and tautness. Ready to drink in 1-2 years.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2010  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: White wines are rare in the Côte de Nuits and this wine is as structured as many reds. It does have strong toast flavors, a juicy citrus character and pear flavors. They go with an apple skin and spice aftertaste, laced with acidity. Drink until 2022.
title: Domaine de Bellene 2011 Les Monts de Boncourt  (Cotes de Nuits Villages)

description: The mineral texture that marks out a fine Meursault is very present here. Yellow fruits balance with this perfumed and intense wine. Still young and crisp, the acidity gives a tight, nervy edge. The wine obviously needs to age, so drink from 2017.
title: Alex Gambal 2013  Meursault

description: Now deliciously ready to drink, this ripe wine has touches of wood toast as well as smooth yellow fruits. It has a warm feel that still keeps minerality and acidity in play. Drink this rich wine from 2019.
designation: Clos du Vieux Château Premier Cru
title: Laurent Cognard 2016 Clos du Vieux Château Premier Cru  (Montagny)

description: While the wine has a steely edge to it, it also has delicious, warm, full yellow fruits, juicy acidity and wood that fits well within the overall structure. For aging over 3-4 years.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2008 Les Caradeux Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: Initially soft, this wine then reveals a firmer structure, and a salty and mineral texture. There is an element of toastiness, rounding out the crisp apple and citrus fruit flavors. A cool, elegant wine.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2007 Les Caradeux Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: Enchanting aromas of grilled nuts and peaches waft from the glass, followed by explosive flavors of smoke, peach and hazelnut. It's plump without being at all heavy, and the finish is clean, minerally and long.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2001 Folatieres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: All 21 of the Puligny vineyards are in this village blend, including portions of premier cru. So it is right that it expresses all the minerality, distinction and structure of its magnificent terroir. But it is more than the sum of its parts, an elegant, steely, poised wine that finishes crisp and tight.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2006  Puligny-Montrachet

description: There is a great balance here between the creamy fruit and the wood flavors. Apricots, ripe apples and melon are spiced with the right amount of toastiness. The wine has a rich, warm feel. It is still young, so wait until 2015 to drink.
title: Domaine de Bellene 2011 Les Charmes Dessus  (Santenay)

description: Smooth and round, this wine is made from grapes that were sourced from the southernmost vineyards of the Côte d'Or. It has a soft, rich and fruity character that shows citrus and white peach flavors, plus a pineapple hint. As it opens, it becomes opulent and full bodied.
title: Domaine de Bellene 2010 Les Charmes Dessus  (Santenay)

description: Still young, this crisp wine has a mineral texture and tight acidity. Along with the toastiness and spice, it is structured to age. Drink this rich, full wine from 2020.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2016 Les Hauts Marconnets Premier Cru  (Savigny-lés-Beaune)

description: Because strong toast aromas show through this wine, its attractive full fruit will need time to come through. The wine, with its firm, almost red-wine structure, needs to age until 2016 before drinking.
title: Domaine de Bellene 2011  Savigny-lés-Beaune

description: This wine is concentrated and full in the mouth, and it bears a minerally texture and intense acidity. It's packed with flavors of sweet peach, lime, ripe Rocha pear and spice from the wood maturation. This promises to age for several years.
title: Domaine de Bellene 2010  Savigny-lés-Beaune

description: Fruity and structured, this strongly wood-aged wine is packed with toast. That dominates the fresh apple and pear fruits that are underneath all this spice and toastiness. Rich and full bodied, the wine is still developing, so drink from 2016.
title: Domaine Ferret 2012 Cuvée Hors Classe Les Ménétriéres  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: A rich and concentrated, yellow fruit-dominated wine. This is white Burgundy at its most opulent, dense and generous. The wood is sweet, reinforcing the delicious character of this wine. Age for 4-5 years.
title: Château de Fuissé 2009 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Still young, this wine has a crisp, steely character, with the freshest acidity which masks the weight of toast and ripe fruit. The austere edge will surely disappear over the next 2-3 years, certainly worth waiting.
title: Henri de Villamont 2007 Sous le Puits Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: The complex nose boasts hints of toast, vanilla, cinnamon and hazelnuts. But don't think that this is an oak-and-mirrors wine. There's plenty of white stone fruits to back it up, along with a minerally edge. Finishes very long, with recurring notes of toasted nuts.
title: Louis Latour 1998 Les Truffieres  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Although the domaine is mainly centered on Chassagne-Montrachet, neighboring Saint-Aubin is hardly far. This ripe, yellow and citrus-fruit-flavored wine is already delicious. Touches of toast from wood aging along with balanced acidity give it both crispness and richness. Drink now.
title: Philippe Colin 2014 Le Charmois Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: With its sandstone soil, the Abbaye de Morgeot vineyard is equally suited to Pinot Noir as to Chardonnay. But it is able to produce fresh, fruity wines, like this one. A spice and citric blend dances on the palate.
title: Louis Jadot 2004 Abbaye de Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Les Fourneaux is one of the smallest premier crus. Rich and balanced, this wine is full of pear and apricot flavors. It combines a minerally edge with a generous structure and fruitiness. Delicious now, but keep it for 3-4 years.
title: Domaine Charly Nicolle 2011 Les Fourneaux Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Weighty, full-bodied, full of ripe yellow fruits. Here's a wine that is going to be a powerhouse, packed with intense flavors, touched by wood and a crisp edge. The aftertaste leaves minerality along with the ripe fruit.
designation: Domaine Long-Depaquit Les Blanchots Grand Cru
title: Albert Bichot 2005 Domaine Long-Depaquit Les Blanchots Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: This is aromatic, with ripeness that balances the bright green and white fruits. Wood and spice notes are followed by a touch of lemon jelly and minerally acidity. It's a wine that is still developing, waiting for the ripe fruit of the vintage to surface.
title: Henri de Villamont 2009 Clos St-Jean Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This is a rich, generous and rounded wine. The opulent feel is balanced by a strongly mineral texture. Old vines give concentration while also allowing for great freshness. It needs to age further. Drink from 2017.
title: Maison Roche de Bellene 2012 Vieilles Vignes  (Meursault)

description: Like so many Drouhin wines, this is beautifully balanced. The wood, green fruit, spice and acidity already in fine harmony. There is a richness coming from the deep soils of the vineyard. Can it age? Probably, because of the firm structure.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2004 Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: The dominant pear and melon notes actually come across as a bit austere despite the wine not being hugely mineral upfront. Where this wine shows its pedigree is on the long finish, which picks up anise and flint notes and a rich, plush texture. Imported by Monsieur Henri Wine Co.
title: La Chablisienne 2003 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Monnot seems to be good at showing off appellation characters. This wine has plenty of typical Meursualt plumpness, the fruit sitting comfortably on ripe flavors of apricots and white peaches. But there is also a core of fruit-skin structure that promises some aging potential. Imported by Robert Kacher Imports.
title: Xavier Monnot 2007 Les Chevaliéres  (Meursault)

description: Big, ripe, generous, this wine is on the rich side of the 2006 vintage. At this stage, it offers peach and apricot, with honeyed yeast flavors. The minerality crispens the texture, while black pepper and firm tannins suggest aging ability.
designation: Le Fief de Grenouilles Grand Cru
title: La Chablisienne 2006 Le Fief de Grenouilles Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: This ripe and fruity wine from the heart of the appellation's terroirs is attractively spicy as well as packed with crisp apple fruits. Balanced and lifted by acidity, the wine still has attractive freshness. Drink now.
title: Domaine du Roc des Boutires 2016 Aux Bouthiéres  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Big and broad with fruit that is full and ripe, packed with golden apple flavors. It has great texture and sweetness, with a well-judged touch of vanilla from the wood.
title: Louis Latour 2008 Goutte d'Or Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: A rounded wine, with a counterpoint of apple skin texture, the fruit flavors offering acidity as well as green plums. The texture is plush, velvet, delicious.
title: Louis Latour 2008 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Very rich, but the wine also has a good steely edge to it, a texture of fruit skins to go with the ripest apricot flavors. It rolls satisfyingly around the mouth, a concentrated burst of fruit that, as with the steeliness, ends with crisp acidity. Imported by Boisset America.
title: Jean-Claude Boisset 2006 Genevriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Youthful yeasty aromas appear at this early stage, the palate showing the same character. The fruit is firm and structured, the acidity very marked along with its tense mineral character. For aging.
title: Louis Latour 2008 Les Truffiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Ripe, rich and soft, this is an opulent wine from a warm year. The acidity is there, masked by toast, apricot and melon flavors. It is already drinkable, likely to continue to age over 3-4 years.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2009 Preuses  (Chablis)

description: Perhaps the best-known of the Chassagne-Montrachet premier crus, Morgeot is a wine that delights the taste buds. Moreau's example has enticing flowery aromas, ripe red apple and fresh almond flavors, and a friendly, open character that is tempered with some fresh acidity.
title: Domaine Bernard Moreau et Fils 2004 Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: With great fruit and a rich, toasty backdrop, this wine has both intense acidity and full-bodied richness. Ripe yellow fruits are balanced by bright acidity and a strong citrus streak that give balance and freshness. It has aging potential and will be best from 2020.
title: Château de la Crée 2015 Les Tillets  (Meursault)

description: Although this is not a premier cru, this 33-acre vineyard sits right next to some of Meursault's finest vines. The wine is mineral, tight and textured- a wine that should age. With touches of oak, spice and intense yellow fruits, it is ripe while still closed at this stage. It certainly needs aging and will be ready from 2019.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2014 Narvaux  (Meursault)

description: From one of the most familiar of the Meursault Premier Crus, this wine is crisp and mineral in character. It has tight acidity with apple and green-plum fruit that is laced by a light amount of wood aging. The wine is still young and will be better from 2018.
title: Domaine Jean Monnier et Fils 2014 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Big and fruity, this is very lively, balancing butteriness with green-fruit acidity. The wine is maturing quickly, its tension is fading into rich, wood-flavored fruitiness.
title: Louis Latour 2010 Meursault Blagny Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Very buttery, this concentrated wine shows wood-aging flavors as well as full, tropical fruit. Rich and rounded, it conveys a fine dense texture. Drink from 2017.
title: Château de Fuissé 2012 Les Brûlés  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Situated at the entrance to the Saint-Aubin valley, this chalky vineyard gives a wine with tight tense minerality. Its lemon and grapefruit flavors are bright with acidity. The wood aging shows through in vanilla flavors that give a smooth edge to the wine. Drink from 2019.
title: Roux Pére et Fils 2014 Combes au Sud Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: A powerfully rich wine that brings in delicious white and yellow fruit flavors. It is unctuous, rounded, made richer with toast then given a boost by a streak of fresh citrus acidity. Good, plump white Burgundy.
title: Xavier Monnot 2006 Les Chevaliéres  (Meursault)

description: This is a very mineral driven wine-the ripe fruit is cut with acidity, green fruits and herbs. Textured and ripe, its freshness is a counterpoint to the full fruit flavors.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2010 Les Chaumes Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This crisp wine is currently tightly closed. It is textured and mineral, with apple and citrus flavors coming through slowly. This perfumed wine needs to age. Drink from 2017.
title: Alex Gambal 2014  Puligny-Montrachet

description: Crisp acidity and citrus fruitiness combine with a riper, textured character. The wine shows the strong minerality inherent in whites from Pernand-Vergelesses, as well as a richer streak. Because of its structure, it should age. Drink from 2016.
designation: Creux de la Net Premier Cru
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2012 Creux de la Net Premier Cru  (Pernand-Vergelesses)

description: This is a blend of several parcels throughout the appellation including some Premier Crus. It has the power of the appellation along with the elegant Leflaive house style. That makes for a fine structured wine with great acidity, apple and pineapple fruit and a strongly mineral aftertaste. Drink starting from 2019.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2014  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: A ripe wine with vanilla and intense structure, it is very rich and almost heavy in character. Generous yellow fruits are ripe and full of juicy acidity. The wood aging just shows along with spice at the end. Drink from 2017.
title: Alex Gambal 2011 Clos Saint-Jean Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: As its name suggests, this vineyard is above the Marconnets, one of Beaune's top vineyards. Beautifully perfumed, it is ripe with orange zest, apples and a streak of delicious citrus acidity. It has a light touch, fruity, with hints of wood and minerality.
title: Domaine Pierre Labet 2013 Clos du Dessus des Marconnets  (Beaune)

description: A big, fat, rich wine with great white currant and white peach flavors. This delicious wine still has fine acidity and just a touch of austerity to give it structure, depth and potental longevity. Imported by Remy Cointreau USA.
title: Domaine Laroche 2003 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Ripe and structured, it has the weight and broad feel of a Chassagne-Montrachet. Firmly textured and concentrated, it also shows soft fruitiness. The power will keep it aging well, so drink from 2017.
title: Louis Latour 2011 Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This is firm, rich and closed, with the fruit showing potential richness under the tight exterior. Packed with notes of wood, spice and a taut texture, this is a wine to enjoy several years down the road. Age for at least five years.
title: Henri de Villamont 2009 Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Producing some of the more refined wines of Meursault, Charmes also has the right amount of opulence. Louis Latour's wine brings out all the richness and ripeness; soft, generous and full-bodied and leavened with spicy wood flavors.
title: Louis Latour 2004 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Firmly touched by wood, this is a rich and also structured wine. It has spice as much as fruit at this stage, the juicy acidity lurking behind the toasty exterior. The wine should balance out but will need time. Drink from 2020.
title: Albert Bichot 2014 Domaine du Pavillon  (Meursault)

description: A good contrast between weighty, rich fruit and a steely structure. White fruits and acidity offer freshness, while the more austere edge gives the wine a serious, solid character. For aging.
title: Domaine Michel Bouzereau 2008 Le Limosin  (Meursault)

description: A deliciously fruity wine that still manages to have some denseness and structure. A touch of hazelnuts and green fruit give extra pleasure; should develop relatively quickly over the next 2-3 years. Imported by Kobrand.
title: Louis Jadot 2003 Champ Gain Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Closed at this stage, the wine has acidity, minerality and the potential of ripe pear and apricot fruit flavors. The wood is showing strongly but will integrate, while the texture promises good aging.
title: Louis Latour 2009 Les Truffiéres  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: A blend from different small premier cru parcels, the wine has weight and richness. It's also driven by acidity and crisp citrus fruits that balance the riper yellow fruit and wood flavors. It should age for at least three years.
title: Manuel Olivier 2010 Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: A rounded, creamy style of wine but with a deliciously fresh green fruit and citrus character. It shows very pure, direct flavors, a line that goes right through the wine. There is only a hint of spice or toast at the mouthwateringly fresh finish.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2006 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: Rich and full in the mouth, this is a wine with structure, tight minera ltexture and beautifully juicy fruit. The acidity is a strong part of this wine, giving a citrus tang to go over the wood aging. Drink from 2016.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2011 Les Chaumées Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: From the domaine of Pierre Morey, who is also cellarmaster at Domaine Leflaive. Like at Leflaive, he works his vines biodynamically. This is a layered wine; the pure, crisp fruit partnering with light toast flavors and a poised and structured apple-skin aftertaste.
title: Pierre Morey 2004 Les Tessons  (Meursault)

description: Almost honeyed in its richness, this is a ripe and rounded wine. A touch of toastiness brings out the apricot and peach flavors along with the rich acidity and soft texture. It's a wine to age, with its fruit and structure still coming into balance. Drink from 2017.
title: Château de Fuissé 2013 Les Brûlés  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This toasty, spicy wine is rich, with a backup of great fruits. The mineral texture gives an edge to the ripeness and brings out the warmth of the vintage. Drink this full-bodied wine now.
title: Marcel Couturier 2016 Le Bourg  (Pouilly-Loché)

description: The wine comes from the Leflaive home village and the blend (from more than 20 parcels) demonstrates the intimate knowledge the family has with its terroir. It has a fine balance between the ripe yellow and white stone fruits and acidity. These are given structure by the wood aging and strong mineral texture. This is still developing and still filling out, so drink from 2018.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2014  Puligny-Montrachet

description: Opulent, rich and flavorful, this is a bold, oaky wine that's brimming with aromas and flavors of baked apple, brioche, pie crust, cloved orange and peach pit. Lush and mouthfilling, the creamy texture and lush flavors are lifted by ample acidity, with a lingering baking spice flavor on the finish. Drinkable now, but should evolve well through 2019.
title: Gérard Bertrand 2013 Aigle Royal Chardonnay (Limoux)

description: This is a lush, rich and toasty Chardonnay, with upfront scents of grilled apple, brioche, orange custard and sweet spice. The medium-weight palate is balanced by ample acidity, lending a freshness to the finish that closes on notes of honeydew melon and toasted hazelnut. Drink now-2018.
title: Gérard Bertrand 2011 Aigle Royal Chardonnay (Limoux)

description: This rich and generous wine has weight, concentrated yellow fruit and citrus flavors. Full bodied, its rounded texture is cut by a mineral element that brings the crisp acidity of the vintage. Developing well, it will be best from 2018.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2014  Puligny-Montrachet

description: With spice and wood right up front, this wine is toasty and rich. It has a creamy texture along with bright acidity and a generous body. The wine, with its smooth, ripe aftertaste, is of course young. Drink from 2017.
title: Louis Jadot 2013  Puligny-Montrachet

description: This is a delicious wine. It offers first aromas of fresh, green fruit, powerfully fruity, toasty flavors, and a fresh vibrant finish. It is not powerful, but it is very enjoyable. Imported by Paterno Wines International.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2003 Clos des Mouches Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: This wine is textured, with a firm backdrop to the ripe white fruits. Acidity cuts through everything, giving a fragrant character. Drink this developing wine from 2018.
title: Louis Latour 2014  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: Starts off with some forceful charred aromas and some rustic, unintegrated notes on the finish, but give this wine some time to settle down and it shines. Grilled peaches and roasted cashews mingle easily with mineral notes, and what the finish lacks in finesse at this stage it makes up in power. Better in 2008. Imported by Vintus LLC.
title: Lucien Le Moine 2003 Genevriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This wine is ripe with yellow fruits and apple acidity. The richness of the year is balanced by crispness, minerality and delicious fruitiness. It will age well, so drink from 2019.
title: Louis Latour 2015  Puligny-Montrachet

description: This mineral, crisp wine offers concentrated acidity and lemon flavors. It is rounded, rich with yellow fruits and with a tight texture that will allow the wine to age. Produced from vines up to 62-years-old, it will be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Maison Roche de Bellene 2015 Vieilles Vignes  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Rich, full, but properly mineral Chardonnay, the wine poised between creamy wood flavors and tight lemon and pink grapefruit acidity. Crispness vies with full-bodied fruit, leaving a deliciously satisfying balance. Drink now, but also worth aging. Imported by Dreyfus, Ashby & Co.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2006 Les Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: White fruits, figs, pears and currants dominate this fine, steely wine, a blend from a number of premier cru vineyards. The structure of freshly peeled apple skin tightens the wine, layering the acidity and freshness. The flavors crispen up on the vibrant, flinty finish.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2006 Clos Saint-Marc Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Elegance is the hallmark of this wine, which flows round the mouth with generous flavors but still leaves a fresh, crisp aftertaste. Green apples, spice and wood all balance well.
title: Etienne Sauzet 2004 Les Perriéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: An elegant yet ripe wine, this comes laced with citrus acidity, and the yellow fruit and melon flavors give it a sense of richness. It's lively and crisp, and it has a toasty base. Age it for 3-4 years.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2010 Clos Saint-Marc Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Blagny is a sector of Meursault with its own series of premier crus including Les Ravelles. This wine, with its minerality and a touch of honey, is rich while pure, clean and full of green-plum fruits. Acidity cuts the wine giving freshness as well as a tense texture. The wine should age a little, so drink from 2020.
title: Chapelle de Blagny 2016 Les Ravelles Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Perriéres is often described as the greatest of the premier crus of Meursault. Wines like this certainly need aging, with their structure overlying the typical opulence of Meursault. It's possible to enjoy this now, but it would be worth waiting 3-4 years at least.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2004 Perriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Ripe and fruity, this has a rich texture that comes both from the generous white fruits and from the cut of lemon acidity. A mineral-textured wine, it's crisp now and will likely round out to bring out the ripeness. Drink from 2019.
title: Château de Santenay 2015  Puligny-Montrachet

description: This wine is pure and fruity, with a strong, tight line of minerality. It is perfumed with apple and grapefruit flavors and a light touch of wood, with good acidity at the end. Drink from 2017.
title: Louis Latour 2014  Puligny-Montrachet

description: Very mineral in character, the wine has grapefruit and orange peel characters. It's taut, linear in style, with a lively acidity that cuts through the citrus and green apple fruits.
title: Camille Giroud 2008 Les Vergers  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Powerful wine, structured with apple skin tannins, layers of ripe, spicy toast and a taut, mineral character. There is something of the Meursault richness here, in the full white fruit flavors, but this is also a wine that needs to age.
title: Pierre Morey 2005 Les Tessons  (Meursault)

description: The freshness of this vintage still shows strongly in this mature wine. Its fruitiness is allied with a touch of toast and freshness to produce a wine that still sings of bright fruit. Drink now.
designation: La Piéce Sous le Bois Premier Cru
title: Domaine Huber Verdereau 2014 La Piéce Sous le Bois Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Produced from one of this negociant's own vineyards, this wine is on the generous side of Meursault. Richness, fruitiness and touches of wood aging are balanced with the crisper, mineral texture that will let the wine age. Drink from 2020.
title: Albert Bichot 2016 Domaine du Pavillon  (Meursault)

description: A finely balanced wine with toast and ginger flavors peeking through the ripe peach and apricot fruits. It is striated with minerality giving an intense ageworthy texture. The acidity shows through strongly at the end.
title: Chartron et Trébuchet 2009 Les Embazées Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Fleshy and full, with complex, tight-knit fruit and oak still resolving into a seamless whole. All the ingredients are there, and the wine seems to lengthen endlessly through a butterscotch finish. A step below the Chevalier, but at half the cost.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 1998  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Tangy and zesty, this crisp wine shows a strong sense of chalky terroir, with a mineral edge and tight acidity. These elements mean the wine will take time to age. Drink from 2021.
title: Bouchard Aîné et Fils 2015 Le Porusot Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: A wine that starts with ripe citrus flavors, then moves easily into soft richness as the spicy wood and sweet peach flavors come through strongly. The wood is dominant, but not excessive. Full, ripe and still young.
title: Pierre Morey 2007  Meursault

description: Very pure lemon and toast flavors dominate this wine. It has crispness, intense freshness and lively acidity. There is also a sense of richness that is slowly developing and that will broaden the wine over the next several months.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2007 Gouttes d'Or Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Although this wine has a strong toasty character, it offers enough fruit, acidity and ripe tropical flavors to make it work. Attractive acidity gives a delicious, fresh aftertaste. Drink from 2017.
title: Joseph Faiveley 2011 Champ Gain Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: This Poruzots offers a restrained version of Meursault, very structured, its texture severe and tight. Apple skin and green plum fruits go with the dry toast character. Age for a year for more ripe flavors to emerge.
title: Roux Pére et Fils 2008 Clos des Poruzots  (Meursault)

description: Ripe, soft wine, the acidity integrated into sweet white fruit and cantaloupe melon flavors. It does have a tang of structure, toast and wonderful final freshness.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2008 Clos des Mouches  (Beaune)

description: Soft, ripe and balanced, this is already a delicious wine. The grapefruit edge to the fruit gives it considerable freshness, but there are also flavors of white fruits, just leavened by toast. To finish, the acidity just bounces out of the glass.
title: Morey-Blanc 2005 Premier Cru Bouchéres  (Meursault)

description: This wine has a good structure and richness. Ripe white stone fruits go with still-young acidity, a taut and mineral texture, and a perfumed aftertaste. From one of the better known of the Chassagne premier crus, this wine will be ready to drink from 2020.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2016 Les Morgeots Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: At the south end of Chassagne-Montrachet, Morgeots Premier Cru is close to abbey ruins. This young, toasty wine is ripe, smooth and creamy. Rich apple and green plum flavors are balanced by acidity and touched by honey. The wood aging is still prominent and needs to tone down, so drink from 2018.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2013 Les Morgeots Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Initially a very soft wine, it slowly shows its ripe fruits, intense texture and blend of buttery toast and acidity. Yellow fruits dominate, bursting through the acidity to give a ripe, opulent finish. Age for 3-4 years.
title: Garnier et Fils 2009 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Opulent, ripe wine, powered by richness and yellow fruit flavors. There is also a mineral tang, with grapefruit and citrus that sits well as the core of this otherwise rich, concentrated wine.
title: Domaine Jacques Prieur 2009 Santenots  (Meursault)

description: Initial high toast aromas soften to bring out spice and yellow fruits. The palate shows more fruit, but still gives layered wood over the citrus, apricot and final acidity. There is a golden feel of superripe fruit. Drink over the next 3-4 years. Imported by Boisset America.
designation: Le Clos Blanc de Vougeot Premier Cru Monopole
title: Domaine de la Vougeraie 2006 Le Clos Blanc de Vougeot Premier Cru Monopole  (Vougeot)

description: Perfumed and textured with richness, this wine is ready to drink. It has the concentration of a wine from this vintage while also having layers of toastiness, minerality and freshness. Drink now.
title: Château de Meursault 2015 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Enticing aromas of pear juice announce a soft, open-textured wine, with ripe pineapple and kiwi along with a pear skin texture. The wine is ready, its fruit and integrated wood open, soft and welcoming.
title: Morey-Blanc 2007 Bouchéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Aromas of wood and fresh apples give a great lift to this wine. It's rich and creamy, piling toast and ripe white stone fruit on top of acidity and good green flavors. It is fresh at the moment, but will soon develop into a great wine. Imported by Paterno Wines International.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2003 Corton Vergennes  (Corton)

description: This is a rich wine with good citrus and crisp apple flavors. It is textured, spicy and has a tight character. The wine is still very young, with a light hint of wood that adds toastiness to the saltiness of the wine. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Jacques Prieur 2014 Santenots Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: With wood and white stone fruit in fine balance, this is a ripe, full wine, the acidity lighting up the ripe flavor. The wine has a broad character, ready for drinking in a year.
title: Morey-Blanc 2007 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This open, generous wine is already completely in its stride. Ripe yellow fruits are given freshness by flavors of orange zest and citrus. The wood aging shows, but gently, rounding out the fruits and adding a note of spice. It's a full wine, ready to drink in 2015.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2012 Les Morgeots Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Corton-Charlemagne should have weight, and this wine has weight. It sits plumply in the glass, a big spice- and yellow fruit-flavored wine, layered with toast and ripeness. It is developing fast, but the lingering acidity does promise 4-5 years further progress. Imported by Palm Bay International.
title: Labouré-Roi 2007  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Still closed up, this is potentially a ripe and delicious wine. As it develops, apple, citrus and apricot fruits will come out, backed up by the steely, mineral texture. The wine is already juicy, concentrated and shows a toasty side as well as rich fruitiness. Drink from 2017.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2012 Les Champgains Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Owner Laurent Godard has made superbly ripe wine, rich in yellow fruits and orange-peel flavors. Generous and full bodied, it is open and ample. Drink this opulent wine from late 2018.
title: Domaine le Virolys 2016  Viré-Clessé

description: Ripe Chardonnay, barrel fermentation and aging, stirring of the lees-all these elements make for a powerfully rich wine, in which the wood acts as a carefully judged supporting act to the intense apples and cream fruitiness. There is just a touch of Burgundian minerality to give some structure.
title: Château d'Antugnac 2005 Les Gravas Chardonnay (Limoux)

description: This wine is ripe, with a warm, yellow fruit character. It is bright and poised, elegant and sophisticated. Acidity shoots through the richness, bringing a strong citrus element. Sunny in character, it will still age; drink from late 2016.
title: Albert Bichot 2013  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: With a crisp texture and ripe apple and pear fruits, this is deliciously fruity and lively, with a lemon zest texture. Some toastiness gives the wine extra interest. It's worth aging until 2015.
title: Rijckaert 2011 En Chantemerle Chardonnay (Arbois)

description: Fruity and fragrant, this rich and complex wine also has a strong sense of acidity. Putting it all together, the wine has weight, aging potential and a fine, zesty, tight texture. It needs to age, so drink this fascinating wine from 2016.
title: Domaine Labet 2011 Fleurs Chardonnay (Cotes du Jura)

description: This wine has an austere character with a hint of tannins in its structure. Crisp apple backs up the bright luminous acidity. Almost startlingly fresh, it needs time in the bottle-drink from 2017.
title: La Chablisienne 2013 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: While there is plenty of ripe fruit in this wine, it also has a delicious, crisp edge that gives the generous texture a good lift. Spice and toast lend rich support to this full, rounded wine. Drink now.
title: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2015 Terroirs  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This wine has a strong tangy texture, tight acidity and a good structure for aging. With minerality and crisp acidity that balances with the concentrated character, this is not a wine to drink now. Drink from 2017.
title: Domaine des Valanges 2013  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: Just a hint of pear peel rises from the nose. The palate is rich with glowing pear fruit, even a little warm, but utterly precise. All this is met with a vein of lemon freshness that brightens all the apples and pears. There is concentration and juiciness, concentration and purity. There is something very fluid and utterly moreish about this.
title: Domaine Charles Baur 2015 Secret de notre Terroir Chard'MMXV Chardonnay (Alsace)

description: Produced from a small vineyard in Pouilly Fuissé, this rich wine is full of ripe, generous fruit. Spice and yellow-fruit flavors blend seamlessly with the soft texture and perfumed acidity. It is developing into a very fine wine, ready to drink from 2017.
title: Domaine Pascal et Mireille Renaud 2015 Aux Chailloux  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Quintessence is a good name for this wine that has the minerality and the structure that are the soul of the appellation. In addition it offers apricot and pear fruitiness and intense acidity. This wine is so drinkable now, although it will be much better from 2018.
title: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2014 Quintessence  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This wine is structured and concentrated, showing a tight character that is closed and firm. It has enough fruit for the future to show its potential richness. Concentrated, very mineral, the wine should not be drunk until 2017.
title: Henry Fessy 2013  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: This is one of the coolest premier crus, meaning that the wine can often age well. In the warm 2015 vintage, the wine shows both beautifully ripe fruit and a tight mineral streak that will keep it on the straight and narrow. It does need to age and the wine will be best from 2018.
title: Domaine Cheneviéres 2015 Côte de Lechet Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Located on the right bank of the Serein, this vineyard produces rich warm wines. This is a ripe full wine with great white fruits that are balanced by spice and fine acidity. The texture is dense and full-a generous wine that needs to age. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Gueguen 2015 Vaucoupin Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: One of a series of single-vineyard bottlings by this producer, this wine comes from an east-facing site in the village of Fuissé. It is beginning to develop, with its citrus and crisp apple flavors contrasting with the mineral texture and tight acidity. Give this wine a few months to fill out further and drink from 2019.
title: Domaine Pascal et Mireille Renaud 2016 Aux Insarts  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This east-facing vineyard is in the village of Fuissé. With the wood-aging giving spice and toast flavors, it is a ripe wine. The wood marches well with the apple and green-plum fruits. Still young, this rich wine has a mineral texture that comes from chalky soil. Drink from 2019.
title: Domaine Pascal et Mireille Renaud 2015 Aux Insarts  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This wood aged wine is ripe, textured with minerality and edged in crisp apple and citrus flavor. Tight now, it shows great potential and needs to develop. Drink from 2019.
title: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2015 Quintessence  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Rich fruit is boosted by the wood aging. Together they give a ripe wine full of acidity and juicy yellow fruits at the same time. It's a delicious wine, smooth while lined with acidity. The wood flavors sustain it, and it should be ready to drink from 2016.
title: Domaine du Chalet Pouilly 2013  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: A mineral and ripe wine, full of yellow fruits along with a tight, steely texture. The combination gives the wine structure and richness, offering ripe complexity and the potential to age.
title: Jacques Charlet 2009 Les Vieux Murs  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Balanced, a wine that shows the right richness, spice, great wafts of fresh plums, peaches, lifted by acidity and rounded by a fine wood element.
designation: Domaine des Deux Roches Plénitude e Bonté
title: Collovray et Terrier 2008 Domaine des Deux Roches Plénitude e Bonté  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This warm, ripe wine offers good acidity, but its main thrust is rich yellow fruits and spice. It is drinkable now, but will develop well over the next few months to give a rounded, generous character. Drink from 2017.
title: Christophe Cordier 2014 Clos de la Côte  (Saint-Véran)

description: This wine comes from one of the cooler premier crus and that shows in the enhanced acidity and crisp texture. That gives a taut wine with some of the steely minerality associated with Chablis. It makes for a delicious, refreshing wine that will be ready from 2020.
title: Domaine Cheneviéres 2016 Côte de Léchet Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: The east-facing vineyard gives cool wines with layers of intense acidity that contrast with the honey flavors of this wine. The two elements give a rich wine but one with plenty of freshness as well as spice. Drink from 2021.
title: Jean-Marc Brocard 2017 Vau de Vey Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This premier cru is on the cooler left bank of the Serein river, making this vintage a crisply mineral wine that's tight with zesty lemon and fine crisp acidity. The hints of yellow fruits are still to develop. The wine is structured and needs to age, so drink from 2018.
title: Jean-Marc Brocard 2015 Vau de Vey Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This wine is textured and tight with delicious, refreshing acidity that is softened by a round vanilla edge. It is still young, still developing its balance and rich, honeyed fruit character. Drink this rich and stylish wine from 2017.
title: Domaine Jean-Paul et Benoît Droin 2013 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Vanilla and crisp minerality play together in this ripe wine with steely core. It has intense acidity, a lively, bright texture plus a flinty edge that will allow it to age. The wine, still young, will be ready from 2020.
title: Jean-Marc Brocard 2016 Vau de Vey Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Grapefruit and other citrus fruits come through the rich fruit. There is power and crispness here, along with a sense of structure from the mineral, flinty character that underlies the fruit. Hold for for 3-4 years.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2005 Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A very vibrant, lively wine, all mineral and fresh acidity. There is some austerity  as the fruit still needs to round out; but it promises to develop well, with delicious green apple and grapefruit flavors. Keep this for 3-4 years.
designation: Domaine Long-Depaquit Les Vaucopins Premier Cru
title: Albert Bichot 2005 Domaine Long-Depaquit Les Vaucopins Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Fruit selected from old vines has been wood aged to give a rich wine with all the elements of a Pouilly-Fuissé. It offers a mineral texture and tight acidity along with ripe yellow and apple flavors that give richness. Drink this wine from 2021.
title: Domaine Sangouard-Guyot 2016 Quintessence  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This is produced from 40-year-old vines that are planted in a walled vineyard. It is a beautifully concentrated combination of pure ripe yellow fruits and intense acidity. Together they create an opulent wine that still has structure and a crisp aftertaste. Keep this wine for a few more months and drink from the end of 2017.
title: Domaine Fabrice Larochette 2014 Le Clos de Monsieur Noly  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Owned by the Fourrey family of Domaine Fourrey, the vines come from two parcels in the premier cru. The wine is rich and smooth with good acidity that balances the ripe apple and crisp pear flavors. A strong line of minerality cuts through this still-young wine. Drink from early 2017.
designation: Domaine des Miles Vaillons Premier Cru
title: Domaine Fourrey 2014 Domaine des Miles Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Lightly touched by wood,  this is a crisp, spice- and apricot-flavored wine. It has a lively feel, laced with acidity and tautly structured. With its mineral texture and young fruitiness, it needs to age for 3-4 years.
title: La Chablisienne 2011 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Steeliness exemplified in wine. This is crisp and structured, complex with its green fruits, structured acidity and touch of caramel and kiwi. It's the acidity that shows at the moment; needs 4-5 years.
title: La Chablisienne 2005 Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: La Chablisienne vinifies this portion of Fourchaume premier cru separately, regarding it as almost grand cru in power. It is certainly a concentrated wine, very ripe, but lined with citrus acidity, crispness and structure. At the end, though, the richness comes out.
title: La Chablisienne 2005 Vaulorent Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Four generations of the Fourrey family have produced wine in Chablis. This latest vintage hails from one of their top parcels. Its crispness contrasts well with the weight and mineral texture of this young wine. Good acidity and a tangy texture indicate a good future. Drink from 2020.
title: Domaine Fourrey 2017 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This normally cool Premier Cru has done particularly well in the 2015 vintage. This bottling is ripe and full of white fruit, while keeping a strong line of fine, tight acidity. It will be ready to drink soon, so only wait until 2018.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2015 Côte de Lechet Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This wine comes from one of the coolest Premier Cru vineyards, giving it an initial austerity that then fills out as the wine breathes. It's crisp and bright with white fruit and intense, lemony acidity. Age it for a few more months and drink from 2018.
title: La Chablisienne 2014 Côte de Lechet Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A wine from one of the group of premier crus that are in the east of Chablis, this is stylish, crisp and comes with a fine line of minerals running through it. It has yellow fruits, vanilla and a hint of honey. That contrasts with the mineral acidity that gives the wine its elegant aftertaste. Drink from 2017.
title: Domaine Gueguen 2015 Vosgros Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This is a very pure wine, all fruit and tight acidity. It is classic Chablis with its tangy, steely edge that gives a lift and structure to the crisp apple fruit flavors. The acidity cuts right through the wine, leaving a refreshing, lively aftertaste.
title: Domaine Cheneviéres 2014 Côte de Lechet Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: From the top of the slope of the Côte de Lechet, this bright and beautifully crisp wine has a strongly steely, cool character. It is structured, full of citrus and sliced apples. A rounder character will come over the next year or two. Drink from 2017.
title: Domaine Vincent Dampt 2013 Côte de Lechet Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This rich, generous wine, always a favorite Premier Cru, offers full-bodied character. With yellow stone fruits, acidity that cuts through the rich texture and a light creaminess, it will age for 3-5 years.
title: La Chablisienne 2011 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Tight and mineral wine, with a great citrus character, fresh green fruits broadened by wood toast, while the acidity is as crisp as possible. It has a youthful apple skin texture, and would repay a couple of years' aging.
title: William Févre 2008 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This is rich, full-bodied Chardonnay, rounded out with peaches and spiced apricots. The wood is evident here, giving an extra softness as well as bringing out rich honey. A wine that opens beautifully in the mouth, ready to drink but also ageworthy.
title: La Chablisienne 2006 Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A premier cru that could almost be grand cru in quality terms, this is a big, ripe wine, the powerful yellow and green plum flavors spiced with some wood aging. There's a great, full-bodied explosion of fruit in the mouth, but the mineral edge of the wine suggests aging potential, perhaps even more  ageable than the 2005 vintage.
title: La Chablisienne 2006 Vaulorent Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This wine is generous and well balanced, with a good partnership between lush fruit and a mineral texture. It is still young but has good potential, and will show its richness and acidity even better given time. Drink from 2019.
title: Maison Stéphane Brocard 2017 Closerie des Alisiers  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Full bodied and rich, this is a generous wine. Its richness and tropical-fruit character is balanced by intense acidity that cuts through and gives it a lift. Drink this ripe wine now.
title: Gilles Morat 2016 Domaine Chataigneraie-Laborie Terroirs de Vergisson  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Fresh fruit aromas are a delicious part of this crisp, fruity wine. It is well balanced, with lively acidity sharing the stage with the ripe pear and pineapple flavors. It's ready to drink now.
title: Domaine Ferret 2015  Pouilly-Fuissé

description: This wine has a tight structure that's laced with wood. The complex fruit is still settling into the structure, promising richness. Age this for at least five years.
designation: Château de Rully La Pucelle Cuvée Comte R. de Ternay Premier Cru
title: Antonin Rodet 2010 Château de Rully La Pucelle Cuvée Comte R. de Ternay Premier Cru  (Rully)

description: This vineyard on the left, cooler bank of the River Serein brings out great minerality in its wines even in warm vintages such as this. Full of ripe yellow fruits, textured and still young, the wine has a toasty character from wood aging. Drink this rich wine from 2021.
designation: Montmains Premier Cru Les Vieilles Vignes
title: Pascal Bouchard 2015 Montmains Premier Cru Les Vieilles Vignes  (Chablis)

description: The wine is ripe and firm with great concentration. It comes from old vines in this southeast-facing vineyard. Rich and full of white stone fruits that are cut with citrus, it is a wine to age. The aftertaste has spice and strong minerality. Drink this wine from 2019.
designation: Les Vieilles Vignes Montmains Premier Cru
title: Pascal Bouchard 2014 Les Vieilles Vignes Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: While the wine has all the steely crispness you expect in a Chablis, it also offers ripe fruitiness that gives a full-bodied, round character. Acidity cuts through to give a lift to the fruit and to the tight texture of this young wine. It should age until 2015.
title: La Chablisienne 2012 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: The wine is soft, fruity and opulent, with apples and a touch of melon. It also has the fine Chablis steeliness that gives a crisp edge to the warm, ripe and rounded fruit. It still needs time to bring out the full fruitiness. Drink from 2017.
title: La Chablisienne 2012 Vaulorent Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Steely, minerally and very textured, this has concentratio and taut layer of acidity to go with the lime fruit. Powered by its structure, it will age for 3-4 years.
title: Romain Bouchard 2010 Vau de Vey Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: To the north of the line of Grand Crus, this premier cru is one of the most familiar. This wine is rich, full and well balanced. Ripe yellow fruits are cut with acidity, minerality and a tangy, zesty edge that is delicious. Drink this poised wine from 2020.
title: Domaine Cheneviéres 2016 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Grapes from this lesser known Premier Cru are often blended with those from Vaillons, yet La Chablisienne has bottled it as a separate wine. The coolness of the site translates beautifully into a crisp fruit expression that's tight with acidity and minerality, ready to age. Drink from 2019.
title: La Chablisienne 2014 Les Lys Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: The warm Fourchaume vineyard has produced a ripe, full wine that could almost come from further south in Burgundy. Just a touch of minerality keeps anchors it in Chablis. A refreshing white fruit flavor follows through into the finish. Drink from 2018.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2015 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: New wood and yellow fruit aromas give an exotic spice- and caramel-flavored wine. The acidity is rounded, sweet, delicious, lifted by intense new wood flavors. This is a rich Chardonnay, well tempered by final crispness.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2006 Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: New-wood aromas, plenty of spice and yellow fruits, but also a beautifully-shaped wine. It's complex yet generous, ripe yet elegant. For village Meursault, this is excellent.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2004  Meursault

description: From one of the best known of the Chablis Premier Crus, this generous, rounded wine delivers ripe yellow fruitiness and a full mouth feel. White peaches give the wine warmth, crispened with sliced apple freshness and a touch of citrus. Drink from 2017.
title: La Chablisienne 2012 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: On the south bank of the River Serein, Sécher is one of the lesser known Premier Crus. This is a cool, crisp wine, emphasizing both green fruits and an underlying buttery touch. Beautifully integrated acidity frames the wine.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2008 Domaine Drouhin-Vaudon Sécher Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A wine that delivers great freshness, a bright lemon and grapefruit character, tautly mineral in character, almost steely, with a pure line of green fruits. Age for 2-3 years.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2008 Domaine Drouhin-Vaudon Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This comes from an underrated appellation, in the shadow of the Corton-Charlemagne vineyard. It's touched lightly by wood aging, showing ripe yellow fruit and a cool streak of minerality. Still young, it's developing well and will be ready to drink from 2018.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2015  Pernand-Vergelesses

description: Very closed after its recent bottling, but shows even more length, minerality and finesse than Robert-Denogent's other bottlings. I've no doubt it will emerge in several years even better. An incredible Pouilly-Fuissé. Imported by Kermit Lynch.
title: Domaine Robert-Denogent 2002 Cuvée Claude Denogent  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This rich wine is dense and concentrated, with beautiful apple and spice flavors lifted by acidity. The fruit and the minerality typical of the appellation give this wine both its fine texture and its tangy fruitiness. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Pascal et Mireille Renaud 2016 Cuvée Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Produced from 100-year-old vines, this wine has been aged for nearly three years and has lost its intense fruitiness. Wood and spice flavors are present along with a perfumed intensity and toastiness. Drink this wine now.
title: Domaine Pascal et Mireille Renaud 2014 Aux Bouthiéres  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This is a warm, creamy wine with layers of toast and yellow fruits. It has a ripe feel and a generous texture, with a mineral backbone keeps the wine in shape. Drink now.
title: Pascal Rollet 2014 Aux Bouthiéres  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: From a relatively cool vineyard on the left bank of the Serein river, this wine is crisp, tight and steely. A strong mineral element partners with the apple and citrus fruits, giving a lively texture. The wine needs to age and will be ready to drink from 2017.
title: Domaine Ellevin 2014 Vosgros Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: From a parcel of the Fourchaume premier cru vineyard that is on the same slope as the Grand Crus, this is a ripe, full-bodied wine, packed with fruit while still firmly structured. Tropical and yellow fruits, hints of pineapple and apricots give richness, set against a mineral, textured aftertaste. Drink from 2017.
title: La Chablisienne 2012 Vaulorent Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A wine that shows the natural richness of Meursault, this is full of pineapple and white peach flavors. This has a fine, tangy structure and a chalky minerality. Age 3-4 years.
title: Manuel Olivier 2009 Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Sometimes blended with grapes from the Fourchaume Premier Cru, this Vaulorent bottled on its own is a bit crisp-bright with citrus and toasty from wood aging. It will develop slowly over several years, so drink from 2019.
title: La Chablisienne 2014 Vaulorent Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Full of fruit, this also expresses a tight and mineral sense of terroir. Tangy, packed with white fruit and green plums cut with lime juice, this ripe, full-bodied wine is going to be delicious. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Cheneviéres 2014 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A soft and round exterior hides the concentrated, structured core that sets this wine on a long road to maturity. Creamed pears, quince and tight acidity are developing to come through and fill the wine with a crisp character allied to steeliness. Drink from 2017.
title: Damien et Romain Bouchard 2012 Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: The wine is fresh, its baked apple and green plum fruit cut with intense citrus. The vineyard, with its pure chalk soil, shows strongly in the minerality and steely texture of the wine, promising aging. Drink this complex wine from 2016.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2012 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A rounded wine with an attractive touch of toast and delicious acidity. Ripe and creamy, it's full of peach fruits as well as having a citrus streak. A more nervy edge twill soften as it ages. Drink from 2016.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2011 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A young wine, its fruit only just settling with the fine acidity and intense texture. The potential is all there, from the wood-aged character to the freshest acidity to the rich peach and green plum flavors. The texture gives the wine a final tang. Screwcap.
title: Domaine Laroche 2009 Les Vaudevey  (Chablis)

description: Lively but rich, this balances freshness, crispness and minerality with dense, delicious fruits. There are caramel and white fruit flavors, along with intense structure. This should age for 3-4 years. Screwcap.
title: Domaine Laroche 2005 Les Fourchaumes Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Only two acres in size, this southeast facing vineyard has produced a ripe, spicy wine. Soft peach and pineapple flavors are rich and opulent. A tang of acidity over the wood aging gives the wine shape. It is still young, so don't drink before 2018.
title: Château de Lavernette 2013 Vers Châne  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: With noticeable wood flavors, this sophisticated wine is smooth, rich and creamy. It has enough fruit to sustain all this toast, giving a wine that has a fresh line that runs right through it, passing apples and fresh apricots on the way. Drink from 2016.
title: Georges Duboeuf 2013 Domaine Beranger  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: From one of the top vineyard sites in Pouilly-Fuissé, this wine is rich and textured, with the tight minerality typical of the appellation. It also has ripe fruit, juicy apricots and acidity. It's rich and crisp at the same time. Drink from late 2018.
title: Camille Paquet 2015 Les Crays  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This vineyard, close to Chassagne-Montrachet, produces wine that shows how good Saint-Aubin can be. Smooth and ready to drink, the wine is opulent in a tropical-fruit flavor and citrus-driven acidity. Acidity guards the freshness and indicates the aging potential. Drink the wine from 2020.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2014 Le Charmois Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: This ripe, almond- and pear-flavored wine has a fine balancing structure of green fruit skins. It's certainly rich, but it also has elegance, restraining its exuberance through the finishing acidity, which promises 5-7 years' aging.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2005 Beaune du Château Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: This wine has spice, juicy wood and good acidity that are well integrated. The rich, smooth fruit character contrasts with the more tangy wood acidity. Together, they bring a wine that has bite, with a mineral as well as toasty aftertaste. Drink from 2017.
title: Verget 2014 La Roche  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Ripe and rich, this is a complex wine, with petrol aromas, canned peach and fresh green plum flavors and layers of acidity. A full-bodied wine, it has a tangy character with depth and intensity from both the fruit and toast. Drink from 2015.
title: Andre et Mireille Tissot 2011 En Barberon Chardonnay (Cotes du Jura)

description: A beautiful wine that floats its minerality, white flower aromas and white currant fruits over a foundation of toast. Freshness dominates this crisp wine, with intensity to finish.
title: Domaine Vincent Dauvissat 2005 Séchet Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This wine is ripe, smooth and rich. It has a generous feel to it, although never far from the more mineral, steely, terroir-driven character that makes good Pouilly-Fuissé. The top of the range from Château de Fuissé, this wine is selected from 30 different parcels giving an harmonious balance between richness and structure. Age the wine and drink from 2018.
title: Château de Fuissé 2013 Tête de Cru  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Not to be confused with wines from the vineyard of the same name in neighboring Pernand-Verglesses, this balanced wine shows ripe tropical fruits as well as toasted wood flavors. It is structured and still developing its rich potential. Drink from 2017.
title: Domaine Dublére 2011 Aux Vergelesses Premier Cru  (Savigny-lés-Beaune)

description: Next to the line of Grand Cru vineyards, this premier cru is one of the finest. This wine has minerality, a steely edge and a chalky character. These are allied to the ripe fruits that hint of apricot and offer both richness and crisp freshness. Drink this wine from 2021.
title: Jean-Marc Brocard 2017 Montée de Tonnerre Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This wine comes from the furthest west of the Chablis Premier Cru vineyards, and furthest from the Serein river. The coolness of its chalk soil reflects in its crisp, appley and tight mineral character. The fruit is bright, in accordance with the 2014 vintage. Drink now, or, better yet, from 2018.
title: Nicolas Potel 2014 Vau Ligneau Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This wine is rich, full in the mouth and with good concentration. Its youthful, mineral character gives it texture as well as good acidity. With its potential and ripe yellow and citrus fruit, it is likely to age for several years. Drink from 2019.
title: Domaine Gueguen 2016 Vaucoupin Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: There's a luscious outer edge to this wine, with mango and peach flavors freshened with citrus. But at its dense core, it is all mineral, flinty, the wood present but certainly not dominant. It needs time, maybe 3-4 years.
title: William Févre 2005 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: At this stage, this wine is quite closed, but the potential is there. When it opens out, over five years, it will have enticing layers of wood, sweet fruit and intense ripe fruit.
title: Louis Latour 2002 Premier cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: A silky ripe wine that has great yellow and white stone fruits. That is contrasted with a strongly mineral character, touches of honey and intense acidity. The wine is still young but it has a delicious future. Drink starting from 2019.
title: Château de Lavernette 2014 Vers Châne  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Close to the slope of Grand Crus, Fourchaume is one of the best known of the premiers in Chablis. This ripe wine with its touches of vanilla as well as yellow fruits and acidity has a lightly honeyed character typical of the vintage. It is ready to drink, although it will be better from 2017.
title: Domaine Gérard Duplessis 2013 Fourchaume Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Balanced, a wine that has both great fruit and sweet apple acidity. Hints of spice from wood, followed by good freshness, giving a wine that is rich and crisp.
title: Daniel Barraud 2008 En Buland Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Rich and soft, the yellow fruit character of this wine shines through the acidity. It has a broad texture, although never losing sight of that crispness.
title: William Févre 2008 Vaulorent Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This wine is properly steely, tight and with considerable acidity. To balance all this freshness it has layers of ripe yellow fruits that are developing and will likely give a fuller wine in a few years. Drink from 2017.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2013 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: From vines planted in 1955, this is a ripe, fruit-packed and mineral-driven wine. It has succulent green fruits, laced with lemon zest and firmly textured. It needs to age for several years to reveal its full potential. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Vrignaud 2012 Fourchaume Premier Cru Vieilles Vignes  (Chablis)

description: Made from 70-year-old vines planted by Christian Moreau's father, Guy, this wine shows extra concentration, certainly, but also the pure pleasure of ripe, delicious Chardonnay. It's initially tight, but the rich green fruits and toast soon come forward to give an impressively big wine, and one worth aging.
designation: Cuvée Guy Moreau Vaillon Premier Cru
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2006 Cuvée Guy Moreau Vaillon Premier Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: Ripe tropical fruits star in this opulent, bold wine. The acidity is there, just enough to give this rich wine the support it needs. It is a complete wine-ripe and spicy, just give it some more time. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Ferret 2015 Le Clos  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This oak-aged wine, made from organically grown grapes, is already delicious. It has the fatness of the vintage in white wines without losing the structure and minerality of the appellation. Warm and opulent, it's ripe with white fruits and finished with acidity.
title: Château de Lavernette 2016 Vers Châne  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: The lovely nose is tinged with floral aromas that call to mind apple blossoms and lilacs, but there's also a firm, underlying minerality. Apple and pear flavors join with limes and minerals in the mouth, finishing long and mouthwatering.
title: Domaine Laroche 2002 Les Blanchots Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Concentrated white fruits, layering melon, pear and red apples with the balancing acidity. For a Chablis, it is ripe and opulent, a delicious already approachable product of the warm year. It does have texture to age well.
designation: Cuvée Guy Moreau Vaillon Premier Cru
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2009 Cuvée Guy Moreau Vaillon Premier Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils
