description: The wine is rich, packed with pear juice and minerality, laying on a tight lemon character, structured and steely, along with a rich texture that suggests the wine will be opening up over the next several years.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2008 Domaine Drouhin-Vaudon Bougros Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: The complexities of Burgundy! This is the vineyard next to the more familiar Les Charmes, just up the slope-hence dessus, meaning above. This vineyard gives a mineral character, hinting at Chablis, but with some Meursault richness as well. Hold this wine, with its delicious vanilla flavors, and it will be ready in a year.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2004 Les Charmes-Dessus Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This wine is both full of exotic fruits and tightly structured. The combination is fascinating and works, giving a ripe side to the steely core. Its yellow fruit hints that this wine will become rich as it develops. Drink from 2019.
title: Domaine Louis Moreau 2013 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: From this rich vintage comes this delicious, open wine. Flavors of tropical fruit and peach create an opulent and generous feel, with notes from having aged in wood offering complexity. It's concentrated and ageworthy, worth keeping for 4-5 years and more.
title: La Chablisienne 2009 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Packed with rich fruit as well as minerality, the wine has all the right tension of Chablis while benefiting from the warm pear, peach and almond flavors. The citrus edge is very Chablis.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2009 Blanchot  (Chablis)

description: This powerful wine reveals its style and breeding from the start. It has weight and concentration allied to great tangy fruit flavors. The nervy edge is very evident, with wood, structure from green apple skins and aging potential.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2008 Preuses  (Chablis)

description: A beautifully proportioned wine, from its rich yet mineral texture to its full grapefruit and gooseberry flavors. It gradually shows toast as well as wonderful acidity. For aging over 4-6 years.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2008 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Taut and edgy, very steely in character, with almost an austere character in its youth. Its fruits are definitely on the citrus side of the spectrum, crisp yet rich as well. The acidity shoots right through the wine.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2008 Blanchots  (Chablis)

description: The fruit here is so pure, its ripe green fruit tied in with minerality, acidity and a lightly cream and toast touch. It has weight, it's still young. Age for five years.
title: La Chablisienne 2008 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: A broad, fat wine, showing soft white fruits and a definite amount of toast. Only towards the end does juicy acidity show through. It feels not yet fully integrated, so hold off a year.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2007 Blanchot Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: While Les Clos is less well known than some other grands crus, it does give an impressively complete wine. Initially rounded, it then shows some many other facets. All the elements are here, the proper steely core, the rich white and yellow fruits, and the shaft of acidity that cuts through the wood and the richness.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2006 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Powerful wine that goes for the big, opulent style. Yet it has the serious intent and structure of a great wine, its minerality intense, the tropical fruits balanced with concentrated acidity. This is a wine that needs at least five years' aging.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2006 Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Open, generous and relatively opulent, showing all the richness of 2005, along with peaches, apricots and tropical fruits. It's round from start to finish, a luscious Chardonnay. Just some crispness at the end.
title: William Févre 2005 Bougros Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Richly textured wine, with pear and citrus fruit layered over an opulent core of ripe yellow fruits and toast. It develops slowly, opening to show intense acidity, freshness and flavors.
title: Louis Jadot 2009 Abbaye de Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Dense and rich, this shows structure as well as powerful fruits. It comes from a parcel of chalk soil at the southern end of Pouilly Fuissé. The wine is firm, concentrated, packed with yellow fruits as well as layers of acidity and toast structure. Drink from 2016.
title: Château de Fuissé 2012 Les Combettes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: One of a range of single-vineyard wines from Château de Fuissé, this is powerful and complex. It's intense, with white fruit flavors that are laced with concentrated, wood-influenced notes. It has an opulent, generous feel, while remaining structured.
title: Château de Fuissé 2010 Le Clos  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Ripe and wood aged, this is rich with ginger and tropical fruit flavors. Dense and concentrated, it is a full-in-the-mouth wine-powerful and very ageworthy. Give this five years.
title: Château de Fuissé 2010 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This is powerful, ripe and creamily smooth, bearing yellow fruits that dominate the wood aging. It's a rich medley of apricot and yellow peach flavors, laced with citrusy acidity. Full, complex and generous, this is worth aging for over four years.
title: Château de Fuissé 2010 Les Brûlés  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: You can almost taste the stones that give this vineyard its name. This is a mineral, firm, tight wine that demands time to develop. The fruit is there, with flavors of white currants, but wait for this wine-at least four years.
title: Domaine Lamy-Pillot 2004 Les Caillerets Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: A signature wine for Girardin, this is powerful and rich, with apricot, quince and green plum fruits that are layered within the taut texture. A toast note rounds out this complex, ageworthy wine.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2010 Les Caillerets Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Soft and rich, with ripe fruit flavors, this is warm and opulent. Packed with notes of spice and toast, the ripe peach flavor is layered into the fine, elegant structure. Aging will make it even more delicious.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2010 Genevriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This is an impressively powerful, concentrated wine. It shows its wood aging now, but those notes should integrate soon into all the ripe apricot and greengage flavors. Richly textured, this is a wine that needs aging, so don't drink before 2016.
title: Henri de Villamont 2010 Morgeots Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Part of the domaine of the Gagey family that runs Louis Jadot, this dense, wood-dominated wine has an austere character at this stage. Ripe, potentially full of yellow and creamy white fruits, it will always have a serious side. Drink from 2018.
designation: Le Clos Blanc Beaune Gréves Premier Cru
title: Louis Jadot 2012 Le Clos Blanc Beaune Gréves Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: Still tight and closed, this has the potential to be a very fine Grand Cru. It has a tight, steely character, a texture that brings out nervy minerality and the beginnings of rich citrus and white fruits. With the light touch of wood aging, this will age well. Drink from 2017.
title: La Chablisienne 2011 Blanchot Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: This ageworthy wine is full of fruit as well as tense and textured. Coming from this ripe vintage, it offers yellow fruits, ripe acidity, hints of the wood aging and a ripe, rich texture. The minerality is cushioned by opulent fruit that is so enveloping. Drink this fine wine from 2021.
title: Domaine Besson 2015 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Very green aromas and a palate that is crisply green-fruited make a great contrast with the more intense Côte Bouguerots wine from the same grand cru. The palate has a very tight, taut character, on the end of an elastic band, with a green, crisp finish. Give this at least three years' aging.
title: William Févre 2006 Bougros Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Very firm, this is a structured, relatively austere wine, with lots of minerality and tightness. The green fruits are  pierced with acidity, but also very fresh. A wine that needs time, give this at least 5-6 years. Screwcap.
title: Domaine Laroche 2005 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: After four years, this wine has developed well and deliciously. The bright, youthful fruit has filled out to give spice and juicy peach while keeping all the acidity intact. This structured wine, from a vineyard almost touching the grand cru Le Montrachet, has an excellent future. Wait until 2023.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2014 Les Chenevottes Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: Ripe mango and tangy acidity come together in a wine that is both textured and opulent. A steely edge will allow this ripe wine to mature well. Coming from the highest vineyard in Chassagne-Montrachet, it has a crisp edge that balances the ripeness. Drink from 2022.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2014 Les Chaumées Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: Right on the edge of the village, this vineyard is one of the oldest walled clos in Burgundy. This 2015 is sumptuous and ripe, full of generous fruit and splashes of toastiness. The wine already has its fruit and minerality in balance. It is tempting to drink it now, but wait for the best until 2020.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2015 Clos Saint Jean Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: The premier cru is right in the heart of the appellation, close to the village. This wine, with its intense fruits and strongly textured character, is still trying out its structure and density. The potential is there with apricot and apple fruits waiting to come thorough the tight structure. Drink this fine wine from 2018.
title: Alex Gambal 2013 Maltroie Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: A beautifully structured wine, with a great zingy, tangy edge to the citrus and toast flavors. It's ripe, packed with melon and pear flavors. Impressive.
title: Alex Gambal 2009 La Maltroie Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This is one of a trio of single-vineyards bottlings from this producer. It comes from the village of Fuissé and is situated in a small valley. Elegant and perfumed, the touch of wood aging enhances the white-fruit flavor. The aftertaste is juicy while also ripe. Drink from 2017.
title: Château de Fuissé 2014 Les Combettes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: A super-rich wine, packed with peach and green plum fruits, layers of wood and an intense concentration. An impressive wine that shows weight and richness as well as style.
title: Pascal Bouchard 2007 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: A honeyed wine, soft and ripe. There is butter and toast, and acidity in the way of white fruits with only touches of citrus. Very round, this wine is almost ready to drink now, with its concentrated fullness and richness.
title: Domaine Vincent Dauvissat 2005 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: An impressive wine, with its tense structure, its ripe pear and melon flavors and its layers of richness. The smooth wood shows slowly and gently as it underlies the fruit flavors. There is also power here, and a definite ability to age.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2005 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: It seems at first taste very rounded, very soft. It is only after a moment that the full balance between acidity, green plums and rounded vanilla comes together. Then the wine shows itself as powerful, but taut, full but crisp, as a Chablis should be.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2006 Blanchot Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: Blending grapes from two vineyards-Les Case-Têtes (broken heads, so called from the steepness of the slope) and Les Murgers de Monthelie-Patrick Javillier has created a big, bold, ripe wine that keeps a mineral, crisp center. The toast from 11 months in wood is beginning to calm down, and this will age magnificently.
title: Domaine Patrick Javillier 2004 Cuvée Tête de Murger  (Meursault)

description: From very stony soil, this wine has a tense structure. It is nervy, the citrus and white fruits striated with minerality. It's certainly a fine wine and one for aging over at least five years.
title: Domaine Jean-Philippe Fichet 2011 Les Chevaliéres  (Meursault)

description: Very mineral to start, only opening up slowly to offer a wonderful line of pure fruit. The texture is important-apple skin freshness dominant, along with spicy wood. This is for medium-term aging-4-5 years.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2008 Les Perriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: An austere wine, tight and taut, drawing a fine line of apple skins and green plum over a steely, mineral character. This is going to take its time, give it 3-4 years.
title: Louis Latour 2008 Les Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: From the famous Chablis Grand Cru, this wine lives up to the vineyard's reputation. Steely in character, packed with a firm structure and tightly textured, it shows a citrus side that will be refreshing and attractive as the wine ages. But it does need time, so wait to enjoy until 2017.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2011 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: A lovely wine that sings crisp Chardonnay, with the added complexity of a taut mineral character and richness from its ripe pear and melon flavors. It will age, its tight acidity needing 2-3 years to soften out.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2008 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: Rich and concentrated wine, with apricot and peach fruit as well as a tight mineral character. This is a wine for aging, its rich fruits bolstered by an impressive integration with the toast, smoothing and rounding the whole wine.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2008 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: From a Picard family vineyard right next to the village of Chassagne-Montrachet, this wine is generous and full of ripe, tropical pineapple flavors as well as plenty of citrus. A balanced wine, it's fresh and rich at the same time. The crisp edge will allow it to age further, so wait until 2020.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2014 Clos Saint Jean Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: Daughter of Roger Belland, Julie has taken over and changed the name of this estate. Based in Santenay, they also have vines in other appellations. This wine, for instance, is rich and structured with just the right amount of wood aging. It has vanilla, spice and great acidity from the citrus and apple fruits. The wine is still young and will be best from 2018.
title: Domaine Julie Belland 2014 Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This intense wine comes from a vineyard just below the main street of Chassagne-Montrachet village. While the aromas are still toasty, the palate is full of fresh fruit, with a tensely mineral structure. Hints of yellow fruits as well as crisper citrus are there, along with shots of toast from the wood aging. Drink from 2018.
title: Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2012 La Maltroie Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: An appropriately rich wine, full, toasty and dense. The fruit is beautifully balanced with ripe acidity, just a touch of spice, citrus and an opulent, full-bodied character. It will certainly age, but is already very drinkable.
title: Maison Jessiaume 2008  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Nervy and textured, this is a wine under tension. It is crisp with acidity, with lots of bright green-fruit and citrus flavors. This is complex and age worthy, bringing out the intense texture from the vineyard.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2010 Perriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: La Garenne is one of the highest in elevation of the Puligny Premier Crus. This wine, with its young wood and ample fruit flavors shows great minerality, texture and intensity. Packed with apple, citrus and ripe yellow fruits, it is still fresh and needing many years to age. Drink from 2018.
title: Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2013 La Garenne Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: This vineyard, at 900 feet, gives a cool take on Chardonnay. It is tight, structured and mineral in character. Vanilla from the wood aging mingles with the taut citrus fruit. The richness will develop as the apricot flavors develop. Drink this fine wine from 2019.
designation: Les Murgers des Dents de Chien Premier Cru
title: Roux Pére et Fils 2014 Les Murgers des Dents de Chien Premier Cru  (Saint-Aubin)

description: Still young, this powerful wine has intense steely minerality to go with its almost stark green fruits. It has a great texture, edged with acidity, and a light toast character. A wine for aging.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2007 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: Fine ripe fruit shows on this full-flavored wine, but there is as much of the vanilla, toast and spice character as there is of the peach note. The texture, though, is all fruit, tight apple skins with final fresh acidity.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2007 Valmur Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: An intense, well-balanced wine with deliciously ripe yet lively green-fruit flavors. The wood is integrated, providing a cushioning richness to what is already a delicious wine. Girardin owns 3.7 acres in Les Folatiéres.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2004 Les Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Valmur is considered to produce a generous style of Grand Cru, and this wine lives up to that. It's warm and rounded while never losing touch with the crisper side of a great Chablis. The ripe white and yellow fruits are on the rich side, cut with citrus acidity and underlined by wood aging. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2012 Valmur Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: Now four years old, this wine has lost some of the edgy minerality that comes from this vineyard and gain a more sumptuous character. Rich white and yellow fruits are supported by acidity and touches of toast from the wood aging. This Picard family wine will be delicious, but give it a few more years. Drink from 2022.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2014 Les Vergers Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: This vineyard just outside the village of Chassagne-Montrachet is one of the best-known premier crus. The wine is pure, with intense minerality and acidity. These elements contrast with the beautiful citrus and green-plum flavors and light hints of spice from the wood aging. Drink from 2021.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2015 Les Caillerets Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: This delicious, crisp wine reveals the more delicate side of Chardonnay. Coming from one of the high vineyards in La Grande Montagne of Chassagne, it has pure, elegant freshness, supplemented by a touch of vanilla.
title: Domaine Vincent Dancer 2004 La Romanée Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Made from 60-year-old vines, evidenced by its concentration and serious ageability. It is structured, firm and relatively dry at this young stage. It's a wine that needs at least 5 years. Today, if you do open a bottle, watch for the mineral, stony character that pushes the fruit and demands attention.
title: Domaine Bernard Moreau et Fils 2004 Grandes Ruchottes Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This beautiful wine offers intense fruit, touches of toastiness and a pure line of acidity. Its succulent texture and generous fruit are layered with the fresher, mineral character of this still-young wine. Drink from 2022.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2014 La Garenne Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: The name comes from the fact that this vineyard was once a truffle bed, high up the slope of Puligny-Montrachet. The wine shows wood, attractive fruitiness and layers of spice and almonds. It is rounded, the soft texture balanced by acidity. Drink from 2016.
title: Louis Latour 2011 Les Truffiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: A very warm, generous, ripe wine, this comes from the most precocious of the grand cru vineyards. It is packed with yellow fruits, rich and open. This is opulence in a glass, boosted by toast and spice.
title: William Févre 2005 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Perfumed white flower aromas lead into a wine that is dense and ripe. As the palate opens up, white and yellow fruits, cinnamon and buttered toast all work their ways into a wine that is almost a meal in itself. Still young, of course, already fresh, it will surely deepen and broaden as it ages. Screwcap.
title: Domaine Laroche 2006 Les Blanchots Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: From Drouhin's own vineyards in Chablis, this is a big, ripe expression of white berry and pear fruits. There is a hint of minerality, but this moves firmly in the direction of richness. Toast and final acidity complete a ripe wine. Imported by Dreyfus, Ashby & Co.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2006 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: All the elements are here in this finely made, well balanced wine. It's fruity and fresh with peach and citrus flavors already well integrated and combined with a fine depth of structure and texture. The after taste brings out the freshness.
title: Domaine Jean-Philippe Fichet 2011 Le Tesson  (Meursault)

description: This is opulent Meursault at its best, all rounded corners, a padded texture and toast mingling easily with yellow fruits. It is delicious now, but with that toast still showing strongly, it should age over 2-3 years to be at its best.
title: Xavier Monnot 2007 Les Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Produced from old vines, this is a beautiful wine. It has great structure, minerality and concentration along with a full-bodied richness that is developing well. Combined with the ripe yellow fruits, they give an opulent wine that will age for several years. Drink from 2018.
title: Château de Fuissé 2013 Vieilles Vignes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Full-bodied, big-hearted, ripe and joyful, this is a welcoming, enticing wine. Flavors of green plums, nutmeg and fresh citrus are part of the pleasure. But so are the open, generous, almost opulent flavors.
title: Etienne Sauzet 2004 Champ Gain Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: The 18 acres of Château de Grenouilles are a monopoly of the La Chablisienne cooperative. A huge, ripe wine, very fruity, with yellow peaches. The richness is balanced with a steely core of minerality. Lively acidity finishes this impressive wine.
title: La Chablisienne 2005 Château Grenouilles Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: This crisp wine comes from one of upper vineyards of the village. It is packed with apples and citrus, plus a touch of toast. With lively acidity, this wine will age well. Drink from 2021.
title: Louis Latour 2015 La Grande Montagne Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Rich and rounded with a creamy texture, this wine is ripe with apricots and has a strongly mineral character. Full of fruit, the wine also has a texture that means it needs to age. Drink from 2021.
title: Louis Latour 2015 Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This comes from the northern end of the line-up of Premier Crus, which shows in the lively, crisp and tightly fruity character of the wine. It is developing slowly, still controlled and with light hints of toast. It will be a beautiful, bright wine. Drink from 2019.
title: Philippe Colin 2014 Les Chaumées Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This is one of Olivier Leflaive's benchmark wines, showing how his winemaker Franck Grux keeps lightness, freshness and complexity all in play. To start, it is firm and austere, then it bursts out with green fruits, toast, white currants and lemon, integrated and balanced. Drink now, or age for 2-3 years.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2006 Abbaye de Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This is a cool wine, with acidity and citrus fruits well in evidence. It comes from one of the higher premier-cru vineyards, giving a crisp and textured wine even in this warm vintage. It needs time. Drink from 2020.
title: Louis Latour 2015 Goutte d'Or Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: As the name says, this wine comes from vines just beneath the woods that crown the hill behind Meursault. Made from 60-year-old vines, it is concentrated, packed with intense green fruits, ripe acidity and a firm texture of minerality and spice. Drink from 2021.
designation: La Piéce sous le Bois Premier Cru
title: Chapelle de Blagny 2016 La Piéce sous le Bois Premier Cru  (Meursault-Blagny)

description: This is one of the higher elevation premier crus in Puligny. In this warm vintage it has managed to give a wine that is crisp and mineral. To contrast with this, the wine also has a creamy, toasty character from the wood aging. Drink from 2021.
title: Louis Latour 2015 Sous le Puits Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: The Belland family has an acre of vines in this prestigious Premier Cru. Ripe while shot through with intense acidity, the wine is finely balanced. Touches of wood aging give the wine a creamy toasty texture. That contrasts with the more mineral fruity character that leaves the wine crisp at the end. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Julie Belland 2013 Les Champs Gains Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: The wonderful combination of ripe fruit and acidity makes 2011 such a good white wine Burgundy vintage. This is an excellent example, with yellow fruit and toast flavors that are cut through with a intensely refreshing tang of lemon and orange zest. Drinkable when young, it is going to age, certainly until 2022.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2011 Les Referts Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: This is a rich and rounded wine, full of yellow fruits that shine through the tense texture. It is ripe, showing minerality as well as tropical fruits and red apples. The wine is going to age relatively quickly, so drink from 2019.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2013 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: This rich, oak-aged wine is impressive and concentrated. With a spicy wood character and ripe apple, green plum and citrus fruit tones, it is intense and dense. The mineral texture, tight and tangy, and fresh finish marks the wine as one ready to age. Drink from 2020.
title: Thierry et Pascale Matrot 2016 Blagny Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: It's not a bad name for this vineyard-Charmes. This wine, which expresses the nature of the vineyard, is certainly approachable, friendly almost. But there's also a steel fist there that demands time. And if you can't wait, it's a great wine to drink now.
title: Morey-Blanc 2004 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Wood and fruit balance in this rich and full wine. The yellow and citrus fruits give a good mix of ripeness and a fresher, more mineral character. The toast, just the right amount, gives the warmth and polish the wine needs. The result is a serious wine, still young, to be drunk from 2018.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2012 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: This offers a tight texture, toast and spice flavors, and intense juicy acidity. With a firm structure and concentration, it has potential for long-term aging. The yellow fruits are beginning to open up while the more citric character is already giving the wine great freshness. Drink from 2018.
title: Chartron et Trébuchet 2013 Les Embazées Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This is crisp, with citrus and red apple fruits that are heightened by the taut structure. Nervy acidity adds to the tense feel while judicious layers of wood warm the finish. For long-term aging.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2010 Les Chenevottes Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Hugely rich wine, retaining its tense textured character while reveling in white fruit ripeness. Concentrated, with the wood acidity and spice mingling with the fruit acidity, this is a wine for long-term aging, powerful yet always very crisp. Screwcap.
title: Domaine Laroche 2009 Les Blanchots Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: This is already a ripe, opulent wine. It is finely spiced, packed with white and yellow fruits and firmly structured. Spice, pepper and a mineral texture all add to the complexity. It's still coming together and shouldn't be drunk before 2016.
title: Maison Roche de Bellene 2011 Les Chenevottes Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Originally better known for its red wines, this vineyard to the south of Chassagne-Montrachet now produces mainly white wines. This bottling is structured, firm and tight, and it promises a future that will always be serious and austere. Keep it for 4-5 years.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2010 Abbaye de Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: While showing some smoky wood, this wine is more about pure fruitiness with yellow fruit flavors given a crisper shot with acidity. Full-bodied and rich, the wine keeps a refreshing brightness. The aftertaste is crisp and fruity.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2011 Genevriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Caramel and vanilla aromas, the palate rounded, poised, with pear and green plum flavors, along with lively acidity, filled out with toast.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2007 Perriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: A crisp, steely, minerally wine that's packed with fruit that is poised to come out over the next few years. It is firm, taut and on a tight rein at this stage. Oak gives a spicy element. Keep for at least three years.
title: Domaine Louis Carillon 2004 Les Champs Canet Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: The vineyard is high up the slope, giving this wine that has good acidity and crispness. The acidity is light and bright, while the texture is concentrated and mineral. It is going to develop as a fine, ripe wine. Drink from 2018.
title: Louis Latour 2014 Sous le Puits Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Champ Gain is on the upper slope of Puligny-Montrachet. This is a rich, toasty and ripe-fruited selection, full of yellow fruit, mango and clementine flavors. It also reveals the minerality found in most wines from this village.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2010 Champ Gain Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: This beautifully structured wine comes from one of the highest vineyards in Puligny-Montrachet, adding to the texture and minerality. With its outstanding fruitiness and excellent balance of fruit, spice and acidity, the wine is set for long-term aging. Don't drink before 2021.
title: Domaine Julie Belland 2015 Champs Gains Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: While there is plenty of toastiness here, this wine also has a pure and fruity character. It is aromatic, full of white flowers and garden perfumes. Complex with acidity, it also offers lemongrass and spice against a background that is textured, nervy and mineral. Drink from 2018.
title: Louis Jadot 2013 Referts Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: This wine is ripe, very complete in its combination of acidity and ripe yellow and white fruits. A touch of spice from wood aging gives richness as well as freshness. There is weight and great depth of flavor, the acidity welling up from right inside the wine. Drink from 2018.
title: Louis Jadot 2013 Les Combettes Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: A wonderful, ripe wine, full of yellow fruits, textured with apple skins and a powerful edge of minerality. It shows power and concentration while offering smooth, rounded fruit flavors that also pack intense acidity and toast. For aging.
designation: Marquis de Laguiche Morgeot Premier Cru
title: Joseph Drouhin 2008 Marquis de Laguiche Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Very toasty aromas mark this wine. While the toast is present on the palate, it also offers plenty of fruit flavors, conveying apricot and white peach along with a citrus edge that brings out the freshness. Drink this wine from 2022.
title: Domaine Buisson Battault 2015 Porusot Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: One of the most familiar of Puligny's Premier Crus has produced a ripe, yet very structured wine. It has intense minerality and a nervy, tight texture balanced with acidity, crisp apple and attractive wood spice. Everything is in harmony on this complex wine, promising a smooth aging . Drink from 2016.
title: Jean-Claude Boisset 2011 Les Perriéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Wood and ripe fruit flavors drive this explosively fruity wine. Its richness is balanced by the acidity from green apple and lime fruits. Spice from the wood aging adds piquancy, leads to a final burst of textured minerality.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2010 Les Pucelles Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Supposedly set on an ancient burial ground, this vineyard is well placed halfway up the slope of Chassagne. It has almond and spice flavors as well as a tighter, steely texture. The wine, with its wood-aging flavors, is still developing. Drink from 2018.
title: Château de Santenay 2014 La Maltroie Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: An enticing mix of toast and white fruit aromas follows through to rich apricot and ripe pear flavors, spiced with the creamy toast. The wood does need to calm down for the wine to be at its best.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2008 Les Chenevottes  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Ripe wine, soft and weighty, the citrus element an important balancing character. Under the generosity, there is a more tautly textured wine, with acidity and flintiness. To finish, the wood shows and rounds out the fruit.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2007 Les Chenevottes Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Rounded wine, with a generous helping of acidity, it balances richness with a defiantly mineral character. There is total freshness and crispness as well as final softness.
title: Domaine Michel Bouzereau 2007 Les Perriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This wine has all the tight minerality of the appellation, surrounded by delicious, ripe yellow and white fruits. The wood aging is still there although balanced with the richness and the intensity of the wine. It is going to develop well. Drink from 2020.
title: Louis Latour 2014 La Garenne Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Dominated by its toasty wood flavors, this is a wine still under development. It has weight, the fruit offering great potential richness. Spice, lime fruits and a firm, steely core all promise to come together into a fine wine in five years.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2009 Champ Gain  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Offering both richness and absolute freshness, the wine layers ripe white and yellow fruits, creamed apple flavors and a great line of mineral texture and citrus flavor. It will age, give this 6 years.
title: Camille Giroud 2008 Le Champ Gain  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Young vines give this wine a bright, fruity character, while wood aging brings out complexity and ripe yellow and citrus fruits. It's juicy and lively, with just the right minerality and tight texture to allow it to age. Drink from 2021.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2014 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: A beautifully shaped wine that exudes richness balanced with lively fresh fruits. There is a tautness and minerality that adds complexity to the pineapple and spice flavors. The wine opens well in the mouth, ripeness and full fruit flavors melding easily. Delicious.
title: Xavier Monnot 2006 Les Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Ripe and toasty, this rich wine is full of generous fruits as well a wood flavors. It shows the honeyed character that appears in this vintage while still keeping tight minerality. It certainly needs to age, so drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Laroche 2013 Les Blanchots Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: A finely balanced wine, with the acidity a pure streak through the white pear and lime flavors. The wine is rich, the wood so carefully judged with the beautiful fruit.
title: Domaine Leflaive 2007  Puligny-Montrachet

description: This rich and concentrated wine is packed with ripe fruit and also celebrates its firm, mineral texture. The combination of rich fruit and good structure make for a wine that will age, ready to drink from 2022.
title: Château de Santenay 2016 Abbaye de Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This stony, mineral wine is still way behind in its development. It is crisp and tight in texture, with refreshing acidity that lifts the white fruits with lime highlights. It's a full wine that will develop well. Drink from 2019.
title: Louis Latour 2014 Cailleret Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Chanson owns four acres, a quarter of this premier cru. This 2011 is smooth, rich and very elegant. Fruitiness is striated by a mineral, tight texture that gives a touch of steeliness. Drink from 2017.
title: Domaine Chanson 2011 Les Chenevottes Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This succulent wine is packed with ripe, rich white fruits, pears and apples that are given a twist by the spice from wood aging. A touch of honey brings out the creaminess of the texture. At the same time, acidity shoots right through this ageworthy wine. Drink from 2020.
title: Château de Santenay 2015  Chassagne-Montrachet

description: The vintage as well as the vineyard gave this hugely rich wine. It has weight, concentrated fruit and toast flavors, the acidity on line right through the center. Peach, pineapple and grapefruit combine to give an impressive, textured fruitiness. Age for 2-3 years.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2009 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: A well-balanced wine, this is full of both fruit and tension. Ripe yellow fruit is sustained by the nervy structure and the crisp, fresh acidity. The wine is likely to develop slowly and richly. Drink from 2019.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2013 Les Champs Gains Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: A rich wine, with delicious juicy white fruit flavors that roll around the mouth. The fruits are right up front initially, but then the structure of toast, apple skin tannins and some spice come in, giving fine complexity, promising good aging. Keep for 4-5 years, probably more. Imported by Wilson Daniels Ltd. Cellar Selection.
title: Joseph Faiveley 2007 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Ripe and rich, this full-bodied wine retains minerality as well as attractive acidity. Crisp lemon flavor is rounded out with peach and apple skin fruits. The wood, already integrated, gives richness and smoothness. Drink from 2016.
title: Domaine Chanson 2011 Clos des Mouches Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: An elegant wine, this is a blend of vines from both the cool and the warm side of the vineyard. It is soft with ripe mango as well as sliced apple freshness. The texture is already well integrated, both tight and mineral on one side and rich on the other. Drink from 2018.
title: William Févre 2013 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Big and bold, this lives up to the reputation of richer Meursault. Yet crispness, a core of tight structure, toast and fresh fruits are always present. The play between the characters is delicious and likely to allow the wine to age over several years.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2007 Genevriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: The reputation of Les Combettes for charm is borne out by this deliciously ripe wine. It has layers of fresh fruit flavors, a touch of spice from the wood, and a long aftertaste. And, for the future, the acidity and the underlying structure promise at least 5 years of evolution.
title: Domaine Jacques Prieur 2004 Les Combettes Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: The wine has so much structure and tension. It is wound up and tight, full of acidity as well as the potential for rich fruits. A steely texture powers up the concentration of this wine, which has a strongly toasty component at this stage. Drink from 2018.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2012 Abbaye de Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: The aptly named vineyard is good at producing wines that are deceptively approachable when young and which age so well. This Meursault follows that model: a generous wine with its ripe spice and yellow fruits. They are balanced by the more citrus and green-plum flavors. Full of fruit while also structured for aging, the wine will be best from 2019.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2014 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This is full of steely acidity as well as complex fruit. It is rich, full of toast and spice that show up the generous swathes of yellow fruits that are just beginning to show their glory. It will develop over many years. Drink from 2017.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2012 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: You can smell the chalky soil on this wine. It has some of the Meursault richness propped by wood, but it is also tight, mineral, a crisp citrus-dominated wine, the fresh apple skins giving it a vivid texture.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2006 Perriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Concentrated and structured, this layers wood and vanilla flavors with a taut, mineral character. With its richness and well-balanced citrus, tropical fruit flaavors, it will certainly age for at least four years. Screwcap.
title: Domaine Laroche 2010 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: This is a structured wine, almost tannic in character. It has a rich, textured character that will allow the wine well. Apple and pear flavors are dominant along with the spice from wood aging. Drink from 2020.
designation: Domaine du Pavillon Les Charmes Premier Cru
title: Albert Bichot 2014 Domaine du Pavillon Les Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This steely, mineral, structured wine speaks of the chalk soil of Puligny. It is firm and crisp, even though the fruit is rich. The wine layers the white fruits and mandarin orange zest with some judicious toast from the wood, leaving spice and ripe acidity on the finish.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2005 Champs Gains Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: A wine with great substance, a rounded, lightly toasty character giving richness. It doesn't lose the freshness of Chablis, with the pear and green plum fruits lifted by a fine grapefruit and lime citrus character. Worth aging for 4-5 years, but already ready to drink. Imported by Wilson Daniels Ltd.
title: Joseph Faiveley 2007 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: From vines in the heart of this large appellation, this is a warmhearted and ripe wine. With wood and spice in equal balance with the white fruits, this is a juicy crisp wine full of great acidity and also with a ripe hint of yellow fruits. This fine wine will be best from 2020.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2014 Poruzots Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Who can resist a wine called Charming? This wine, in this ripe vintage, lives up to the name with its open, ripe yellow and white fruit, crisp touch of citrus and creamy wood-aging flavors. The wine shows a generous texture along with the youthful fruit. Drink from 2022.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2015 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Appropriately big and burly, full of ripe fruit, rather soft as well as rich. With its yellow fruits, layers of white currants and a powerful wood element, this is a wine that is still knitting together. There is potential here, especially from the underlying acidity. Give it 4-5 years.
title: Roux Pére et Fils 2005  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Great mineral wine, with wonderful lemon and pineapple flavors. The texture is light, balancing wood, acidity and crisp fresh fruit. The wine has all the elements for aging.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2008 Les Folatiéres  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Located just south of the village of Meursault, this vineyard is in the heart of the run of Premier Cru. The wine sings of Meursault, crisp, fruity with just a hint of a buttery texture and plenty of delicious acidity. It's rich and generous, with a tight mineral texture as well. Drink from 2021.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2015 Poruzots Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Intense and concentrated, this epitomizes the richness of 2005. The wine starts soft, with more spice than fruit, then flavors of peach and quince come through, followed by an almost tropical element. The intensity stays right through the finish of this impressive, powerful wine.
title: Remoissenet Pére et Fils 2005 Les Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: This is grandiose, with ripe apricot and peach flavors-even a note of mango-that are allied to the wood notes. As a contrast, there is fine acidity and elegance, with a lemon zest edge that gives structure to this full, superripe, powerful effort.
title: Henri de Villamont 2009  Corton-Charlemagne

description: This ripe, wood-aged wine is beautifully structured, with vibrant acidity that cuts through the richness of fruit and oak. A taut edge provides an ageworthy build. It comes from a vineyard at the northern end of the village, next to Meursault. Drink from 2019.
title: Jean-Marc Boillot 2016 Champ-Canet Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: This vineyard is at the heart of the fine run of premier crus that lie midway up the slope above the village. This wine is packed with fruit and also with intense acidity and minerality. It is already refreshing and crisp, although as the toastiness develops, it will become even more impressive. Drink from 2017.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2014 Les Champgains Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Showing the typical power of Corton-Charlemagne, this is a classic wine that offers full-on fruit allied to a strong wood element. It is rich and bold, flavored with white fruits, apricots, almonds and spice. While it is drinkable now, it would certainly repay cellaring for 3-4 years.
title: Maison Champy 2006  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Made from fruit sourced from vines close to Puligny's grand crus, this has some of the same structure and dense minerality as many of the village's best wines. It's vivid, upfront and rich with boisterous fruitiness. The structure will take many years to round out.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2010 Les Pucelles Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: This is a strongly mineral wine, rich in ripe apricot and pear fruits and well balanced. Acidity and generous fruits offset each other well for richness and crispness. From one of the most familiar of the premier crus in Puligny, it has great potential. Drink from 2021.
title: Château de Santenay 2015 Les Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: This attractively named vineyard has produced an equally attractive wine. With its good mix of ripe fruits, acidity, nutmeg and spice from wood aging and a generous texture, it is an opulent wine although it still needs aging. Drink from 2021.
title: Maison Roche de Bellene 2015 Charmes Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Using grapes sourced from 50-year-old vines, this is a powerful expression of rich Chardonnay. It has great depth of flavor, with concentrated, intense and ripe yellow and white fruits, spiced from having aged in the wood. Allow to age for over five years.
title: Pascal Bouchard 2009 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: A gorgeously ripe wine, its rounded yellow fruits tempered by wood aging. There is a mineral core, with a steely character to go with the pure pleasures of the rich fruit. The wine is fruity now, and does need to age to bring out the rest of its complex flavors.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2009 Les Folatiéres  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Latour's signature wine is huge in 2003-certainly less subtle and less grand than the 2002, but still a great wine. It is rich, ripe and creamy, with toast and wood nuances. The power is dominant, but there is still the recognizable elegance of a fine Corton-Charlemagne. Imported by Louis Latour.
title: Louis Latour 2003 Corton Charlemagne  (Corton-Charlemagne)

description: There is a definite richness to this wine, the ripe white fruit and melon flavors aided by a judicious amount of vanilla and toast. That makes the wine seductive, but Laroche does not forget its Chablis origins and leaves enough room for a core of grapefruit, steel and tight acidity. Screwcap.
designation: Réserve de l'Obédience Les Blanchots Grand Cru
title: Domaine Laroche 2006 Réserve de l'Obédience Les Blanchots Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Big, opulent and rich, this is all fruit. While there is a hint of wood, the wine is generous with tropical flavors and ripe white pears. If it wasn't for the acidity, this could be New World.
title: Domaine Bertagna 2004 Corton-Charlemagne  (Corton-Charlemagne)

description: A deliciously fruity wine, its bright apricot, pineapple and peach flavors open and generous. Of course, there is a more serious core of structure, lemon zest and dryness to promise aging. At the end, though, fruit and a light toastiness give immediate pleasure.
title: Domaine Leflaive 2009 Clavoillon Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: From the largest of the white wine Grand Crus, this wine has the richness and weight typical of its appellation. It is opulent, majestic with intense white fruits and a broad structure that is balanced with minerality and a crisp edge of acidity. The Picard family wine should be aged for several years. Drink from 2022.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2015  Corton-Charlemagne
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: Tasted twice, two months apart. This wine was fabulous on both occasions, combining the fat, fleshy ripeness and honeyed fruit of the vintage with the minerality of its grand cru site. Smoke, citrus and toasted nuts round out the flavors, which finish long and complex. Delicious now, but should hold several years at least. Imported by Vintus LLC.
title: Lucien Le Moine 2003  Corton-Charlemagne

description: While the wine does have richness, it's the mineral and citrus side that is coming through at this stage. The balance with the wood aging is so right that you feel the toast rather than tasting it. As it matures, the wine will deepen in intensity and power, certainly over the next 5-10 years.
designation: Sous le Dos d'Ane Premier Cru
title: Domaine Leflaive 2007 Sous le Dos d'Ane Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: From a Picard family vineyard that is partly Grand Cru and partly Premier Cru, this rich, rounded wine is gorgeous. The almost tropical flavors herald the wine's richness, spiciness and contrasting acidity. It is both fresh and rounded, generous and crisply textured. The wine will develop fast, and should be drunk from 2020.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2014 Les Demoiselles Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: Really ripe wine, with toast and yellow fruits, laced with intense citric acidity and a mineral edge, to go with the mouthwatering fruit. Needs to age for 5-6 years.
designation: Sous le Dos d'Ane Premier Cru
title: Domaine Leflaive 2008 Sous le Dos d'Ane Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: Juicy acidity cuts through this firmly structured, mineral wine. Great swathes of fresh citrus and ripe apricots go with the toastiness and dense texture. This is a very terroir-driven wine with a long future. Drink from 2018.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2012 Les Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: This wine is crisp and fruity. With acidity as well as a light toast character, it is already balanced, bringing yellow and melon fruit flavors into the mineral texture. Drink from 2022.
title: Domaine Buisson Battault 2015 Genevriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: This wine has plenty of fruit, but even in the open 2013 vintage, it is still firm, structured and with nervy minerality. The richness and the ripe yellow fruits are still to come, meaning that this complex wine should wait until 2018.
title: Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2013 Les Demoiselles Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: All structure and textured fruit, this is a wine for the long term. All the elements are there, although restrained by the vintage. The yellow fruits are more peach than apricot, while wood is still domiNAt. But it does have the power and should be aged for 4-5 years.
title: Roux Pére et Fils 2008 Corton-Charlemagne  (Corton-Charlemagne)

description: The power of Corton-Charlemagne is apparent in this dense, ripe wine. Rich and generous, this selection has tropical fruit flavors that are balanced by citrus notes, and the wood influence acts as subtle support.
title: Maison Jessiaume 2010  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Rich while firm, this wine is structured and dense. It has great fruit potential that is still developing through the tight texture and the concentrated structure. It will be a fine wine, but give it time. Drink from 2020.
title: Chanson Pére et Fils 2013 Perriéres Premier Cru  (Meursault)

description: You can feel the wood, rather than tasting it, such is the delicious fruit character: layers of ripe white fruits, shot through with citrus, white figs and crisp nectarine. The wine is edging towards youthful austerity but the fruit gives it great life and freshness. Imported by Robert Kacher Imports.
title: Domaine Laleure-Piot 2007  Corton-Charlemagne

description: This is a balanced, ripe and wood-aged wine that is intense and seductively attractive. It has a yellow fruit flavor, with acidity and a superb edge of wood. This should age well.
title: Maison Jessiaume 2009  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Still young, this is a wine that needs to open and ripen. But already there are signs of richness, a wood- and tropical fruit-flavored wine that is typical of the full character of a Corton Charlemagne. It would be worth keeping 2-3 years for the wood to soften, the fruit to round out.
title: Bertrand Ambroise 2006  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Great white fruits, hints of peach and tight citrus-zest texture all give this wine its great freshness. At the same time the texture suggests minerality and a nervy edge. Hints of the wood are just right for this intensely fruity wine.
title: Domaine Jacques Prieur 2014 Les Combettes Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Barrel fermentation and aging have given this wine its ripe character. They have filled it out with spiciness, adding complexity to the yellow fruit and maturing acidity. It's not going to age much further but is very fine to drink now.
title: Nicolas Potel 2012  Corton-Charlemagne

description: This wine has the power associated with this appellation, giving richness even while it is still so young. Its weight, spice and acidity are there, packed into a tight parcel that will need to age. Drink this powerful, toasty wine from 2022.
title: Lucien Muzard et Fils 2016  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Rich and rounded, with the toast sinking into the the rich yellow fruit and spice. The wine is gorgeous, opulent, while retaining an intense acidity and an edge of minerality. For medium-term aging.
title: Domaine Leflaive 2008 Les Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: A tense, mineral wine, striated with citrus zest and toast. The wine is tight, nervy in character, holding back its future richness under a firm structure. Keep for four years at least.
title: Domaine Leflaive 2008 Les Combettes Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Bouchard is in the fortunate position of having vines at all heights on the slope of this great vineyard. That gives a complete picture of the richness of the wines, the open fruitiness of this grand cru. Yellow-fruit flavors  are accented by wood and spice. The wine also has good acidity, and fine structure for aging. Imported by Clicquot Inc.
title: Bouchard Pére & Fils 2003 Chevalier Montrachet  (Chevalier-Montrachet)

description: Classically powerful and rich, this is a concentrated wine. With spice from the wood aging prominent, it is still young. That spice is balanced by the ripe yellow and baked-apple fruits. The aftertaste has delicious flavors of honey and lemon. Drink this wine from 2020.
title: Jean-Luc and Paul Aegerter 2014  Corton-Charlemagne

description: So elegant, soft, ripe and generous. The initial take is that it is open in character. Then the more taut, nervy, apple skin and toast flavors come into the balance to give a wine with considerable aging potential.
title: Louis Latour 2009 Criots-Bâtard-Montrachet  (Criots-Bâtard-Montrachet)

description: There is an explosion of ripe yellow fruit here, giving a ripe, tropical feel. Spice, mango, it's quite a powerhouse of flavors. This is a gorgeous, opulent wine.
title: Louis Latour 2008  Bâtard-Montrachet

description: From a small parcel of vines, less than one acre, this is a textured wine. Wood, spice and toastiness are all there, along with lively acidity and a strong mineral texture. It is rich, potentially a wine with a great future and not to be drunk before 2020.
title: Domaine Jacques Prieur 2014 Perriéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Ripe and full-bodied, this immense wine has rich layers of tropical fruits. The wine, like so often in Corton-Charlemagne, is a powerful, huge expression of Chardonnay. It does have balance from acidity. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Faiveley 2011  Corton-Charlemagne

description: Very mineral, textured wine, its acidity and taut green fruit flavors firmly in evidence. It has some of the richness and opulence of the vintage, with great swathes of ripe yellow fruits developing. For long-term aging.
title: Louis Latour 2009 Bâtard-Montrachet  (Bâtard-Montrachet)

description: In this generous and opulent wine, weight and richness accompany acidity and power. Ripe yellow and white fruits are given a touch of spice and new wood. It's gorgeous, but will be better after aging. Drink from 2018.
title: Louis Latour 2011 Les Demoiselles  (Chevalier-Montrachet)

description: Considerable wood flavors mask the ripe fruits at this stage. A rich, perfumed wine, it will bring huge, ripe flavors of pineapple and peach, as well as a powerful toasty character. Give it until 2018.
title: Domaine Faiveley 2011  Bienvenues Bâtard-Montrachet

description: A beautifully elegant wine, wearing its fresh fruit and acidity on its sleeve at the moment, but promising depth of fruit skin and toast flavors as the structure develops. There's a fine tight, final mineral edge.
title: William Févre 2007 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A concentrated, rich wine, very mineral and textured in character. It comes from old vines that give a dense character and layers of citrus, apple and yellow fruit flavors. A strong steely edge, very taut, still shows the wine's youth. Drink from 2018.
designation: Les Vieilles Vignes Montmains Premier Cru
title: Pascal Bouchard 2012 Les Vieilles Vignes Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: A very taut wine. Yes, it has richness and weight with ripe fruits, but the main character is dominated by a tense line of acidity, of very crisp fruit and of an intense steely texture. For aging over 4-5 years.
title: William Févre 2008 Montmains Premier Cru Domaine Févre  (Chablis)

description: Selected from parcels across the estate, this wine aims to reflect the totality of the appellation. It succeeds with its combination of minerality and ripe fruit. Oak, almond and citrus fruits are still right up front, showing that this is a young wine that will age well. Drink from 2018.
title: Château de Fuissé 2014 Tête de Cru  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: Structured and with a strongly crisp and textured character, this wine also has a touch of toast from wood aging. Ripe green and yellow fruits are part of the concentration and dense flavors. It is still young, so wait until 2018.
title: Domaine Pinson 2013 Montmains Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: There are plenty of toasty aromas to this rich, generous and structured wine. It is now almost mature although the fresh apples, spice and vanilla are still offset by the tightest, refreshing acidity. The wood flavors are well balanced by the fine fruit. Drink now.
title: Domaine Vincent Dauvissat 2010 Vaillons Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: From just south of the run of Grand Cru vineyards, this wine is ripe- full of sun as well as acidity. Juicy with swathes of lemon and crisp green apple fruit, it's textured, tight and likely to age well. The estate has been owned by Nuits-St.-Georges-based Domaine Faiveley since 2014. Drink from 2020.
title: Domaine Billaud-Simon 2014 Mont de Milieu Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: Valmur sits in the middle of the grand cru region, forming a valley bordering Vaudesir and joining Les Clos (Févre owns sites on both sides of the border). This is a stylish, intense wine with a slightly smoky quality to the powerful fruit. It sets up beautifully in the midpalate-firm and expansive. Layers of stone, mineral and crisp fruit are highlighted by a tangy saltiness that really sings with oysters.
title: William Févre 1998 Valmur  (Chablis)

description: This is beautifully rich and powerful, with tropical fruit flavors and a hint of wood. It has enormous concentration of sweet, ripe white and yellow fruits, balanced by the sharp cut of acidity.
title: Domaine Jean-Paul et Benoît Droin 2010 Valmur Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: An impressively ripe wine that still keeps its structure and sense of place. There's a chalky-steely character to go with the richness. Green plums are merged with apricots to show great fine fruit. Age five years.
title: Louis Jadot 2009 Les Referts Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: An intense, complex wine that flows unctuously with rich white fruits, spice, vanilla, some toast and a great depth of flavor. At this stage, the toast is quite dominant, but the rich fruit is on its way up. Like many great white Burgundies, this wine needs to be opened well in advance of drinking.
title: Louis Jadot 2004 Champ Gain Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Vaulorent is on the same slope as the Grand Crus, giving it an extra structure. Very ripe and forward, this wine shows both power and the approachability of the vintage. It has plenty of freshness while also showing off yellow fruits and pineapple richness. A more textured, steely, crisp aftertaste will allow the wine to age. Drink from 2018.
title: William Févre 2013 Vaulorent Premier Cru  (Chablis)

description: This full, rich wine is still young, but its toastiness, ripe apricot and pear flavors and intense spiciness all point to a good future. The wine has weight, ripe fruits and a tight texture. Drink from 2021.
title: Domaine Jean Féry & Fils 2016 Abbaye de Morgeot Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This is powerful, typical of Les Preuses. White and yellow fruits are important to the palate, but so are rich, honeyed toast, minerality and an opulent, intense concentration. This is impressive, elegance with power, and worth aging for several years.
title: La Chablisienne 2006 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: From the grandest of the Grand Cru vineyards, this wine is powerful and structured. Its intense white and yellow fruit gains extra richness from subtle wood aging. It's juicy, ripe and full in the mouth. Drink from 2021.
title: La Chablisienne 2014 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: From the most southerly of the Grand Cru vineyards, this wine is firm and tightly structured. Its wood aging shows in its toasty, spicy character that will integrate as the wine ages. Its rich yellow fruit and taut acidity suggest it will taste best from from 2021.
title: La Chablisienne 2014 Blanchot Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Produced from vines high up the Grand Cru slope, this wine is finely textured and stylish while also full-bodied. It has weight, spice from wood aging, precise acidity and a strongly mineral, salty edge. Drink from 2021.
title: La Chablisienne 2014 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: This firm and steely wine expresses power and minerality. Wood-aging toastiness and a taste of honey give a sweeter side to the crisp, tight texture. This powerful, dense wine will age for many years. Drink from 2019.
title: Pascal Bouchard 2012 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: The broad character of Bougros is evident here in this rich and creamy wine. Delicious pear and sweet grapefruit flavors combine easily with a delicate touch of wood, leaving a fine, juicy acidity.
title: William Févre 2008 Bougros Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: The grandest of the Chablis Grand Crus has produced a structured, still very young, wine. With its ripe apple and Bartlett pear fruit and tight, chalky mineral texture, it will be impressive once it unwinds. Drink from 2020.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2014 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: This wine is young, surprisingly fruity at this stage for this normally textured, structured Grand Cru. A pure line of sliced apple and green-plum flavors are shot through with tangy acidity. The fruitiness and intense acidity will pass soon and the wine will develop the proper steely, tight and mineral character. It will drink at its best from 2020.
title: Domaine Louis Moreau 2014 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Serious Chablis, full-bodied and complex. The structure is rich, layering chewy minerality with pure acidity over green and white fruits. The wine opens slowly, unfolding its ripeness and structure. Age for five years and more.
title: La Chablisienne 2010 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Firm and closed, this shows both richness and minerality. It has hidden power, concentration and a steely edge. It's crisp and densely packed with minerality and ripeness. For aging over at least seven years.
title: Domaine Jean-Paul et Benoît Droin 2010 Grenouilles Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: A tight and steely wine, very much in its infancy. It is taut, the texture dominated by green apple skins, herbs, some light toast. This is a complex, impressive wine, its rich fruit still to show. Keep for 4-5 years and more.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2009 Les Clos  (Chablis)

description: Still tasting young, with its lemon and lime flavors dominant, this is going to be a serious, mineral-driven wine. It has plenty of fruit, but it is caged in a firm, tight texture of green fruits. Obviously it needs aging.
title: Simonnet-Febvre 2007 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: While this wine shows huge amounts of toasty wood at this stage, its potential for balancing out is all there. The fruit under the wood is hugely ripe, combining sweetness with lemony acidity in a fine balance. Give it 10 years.
title: Louis Jadot 2002  Corton-Charlemagne

description: In the opulent 2015 vintage, this is a particularly opulent wine. Its ripe fruits are laced with unusually prominent toastiness that needs to integrate better. The yellow fruit though is gorgeous, cut with lemon and a rounded final texture. The wine is sourced from a number of plots planted in 1933 by Guy Moreau, the grandfather of the present winemaker Fabien Moreau.
designation: Vaillon Premier Cru Cuvée Guy Moreau
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2015 Vaillon Premier Cru Cuvée Guy Moreau  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: Bougros is one of the richest, opulent of the Grand Cru Chablis. In this fruit-driven year, the wine is wonderfully spicy, rich and full of fine fruit. Yellow fruits dominate the balancing citrus and wood flavors. It is so forward that it could be drunk now, but this fine wine will be much better from 2019
title: Jean-Marc Brocard 2014 Bougros Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Impressively rich, this is smooth, dense and opulent in its concentration. It's full both of fresh acidity and toasty rich flavors that fill the mouth. The background is the steely texture that gives the wine a fine bite at this young stage. Drink from 2019.
title: La Chablisienne 2011 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: The most serious of the Chablis Grand Crus has produced here a wine that combines that firmer nature with generous yellow fruits, toast and tender acidity. A strong sense of structure partners with a steely core and mineral texture that firms up the fruit and promises aging. Drink from 2017.
title: La Chablisienne 2011 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: A big, burly Chablis, beautifully ripe, exhibiting powerful fruits overlaying a core of citrus and apple skin texture. The wine is open, rich, with an enticing juicy character, finished with bright, ripe acidity.
title: William Févre 2007 Bougros Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: A salty nudge in this ripe wine gives a tangy edge to the rich apricot and spice flavors. Warm and generous, it keeps an edgy acidity that shows its aging potential. Still tight while fruity, the wine that comes from the westernmost of the grand crus will be ready to drink from 2022.
title: Jean-Marc Brocard 2015 Bougros Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Highest up the slope of all the Premier Crus in Chassagne-Montrachet, this vineyard sides onto the valley leading to Saint-Aubin. The style of this wine is just a little cooler and more textured than other premier crus from the village, giving more minerality as well as apple and apricot flavors. Drink this wine from 2023.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2015 Les Chaumées Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: Almost touching the Grand Cru of Le Montrachet, this vineyard produces classic examples of Chardonnay. In this rich vintage, the wine is unctuous, ripe and full of the generous fruits. It also has structure and acidity that will allow the wine to age for many years. Drink this wine from 2023.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2015 Les Chenevottes Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: Structured and tight, this mineral-driven wine is still in its initial stages of development. It has crisp acidity, layers of spicy wood and a rich palate. Apples and white peach emerge from the firm, young structure. Drink this wine from 2018. The vineyard is next door to the Grand Cru Montrachet vines.
title: Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2012 Les Chenevottes Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: An intense, mineral-driven wine, tasting of the limestone soil as well as very ripe fruit. Great acidity keeps the richness in line, toast offering sweetness. The wine is full-bodied, the flavors going right through to the apple-skin-textured core.
title: Olivier Leflaive 2009 Clos Saint Marc Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: One of three single-vineyard wines from this historic estate, this is structured, tight and with a crisp apple and citrus character. Against this is the richness of the wine and its potential for aging. It is a taut wine while also richly fruity. Drink from 2020.
title: Château de Fuissé 2015 Les Combettes  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: The wine is currently closed up, not offering huge flavors. So it is a question of feeling the richness, the steely edge and the yellow fruits. It is certainly very dense, needing several years' aging, finishing with vanilla creaminess.
title: Domaine Michel Bouzereau 2007 Le Cailleret Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Still young, of course, but already the wine is showing great fruits, smoothed by wood, offering style and sophistication. As it opens up, the flavors of pears and sweet apples join the toast and the ripeness. This is on the path to greatness; give it 5-6 years and more.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2007 Clos des Mouches Premier Cru  (Beaune)

description: This is a poised, elegant wine, balancing ripe fruits against a perfumed and textured character. It is young, with bright fruits still to the fore. Acidity and minerality play their part in giving this wine its structure and aging potential. Drink from 2022.
title: Jean-Marc Brocard 2016 Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: A touch of spice and vanilla from wood aging is balanced by ripe yellow fruits and honey. This wine is freshened by lime-juice acidity that gives a crisp texture. Behind all this fruit is a dense structure, weight and concentration. It's a generous wine that will age further; drink from 2017.
title: La Chablisienne 2012 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Taut, tight, steely wine that is immensely concentrated. This is classic mineral-driven Chablis, the crisp citrus fruit and pear flavors integrated into a dominant structure. It needs aging, 5-6 years or more.
designation: Domaine Drouhin-Vaudon Les Clos Grand Cru
title: Joseph Drouhin 2008 Domaine Drouhin-Vaudon Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Big, powerful brush strokes of ripe fruits, spice and rich creaminess paint this wine with vividness. The fruit envelops the mouth, the pears, green plums and ripe apples working with a citrus edge. Impressive, and with a great finishing freshness.
title: William Févre 2006 Les Preuses Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: Ripe kiwi and tropical fruits come from this luscious Picard family wine. It offers acidity and freshness, but opulence dominates at this stage in the wine's development. The wine has good potential, with acidity, wood-aging flavors and spice at the end. Drink from 2022.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2014 La Maltroie Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve

description: Crisp and packed with lively lemon-like acidity, this wine shows both minerality and intense fruitiness. Textured and tight, it has hints of yellow fruit in the background that will blossom as the wine develops. Drink from 2021.
title: Alex Gambal 2014 La Maltroie Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: Julie Belland, the sixth generation to run the family's 57-acre estate, has produced an impressive wine from this great vineyard first planted in the 15th century. It is packed with ripe apple and quince flavors refreshed by good acidity. It's a wine to age, so don't drink before 2020.
title: Domaine Julie Belland 2015 Morgeot Clos Pitois Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)

description: This wine is closed and tight at this stage of its development, which is not a bad thing because it will age well. For now, it offers crisply fresh fruit layered with wood aging and with a tight, tangy texture. Spice and toast flavors complement the fruit. Drink this wine from 2018.
title: Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2012 La Garenne Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Perfumed, floral and ageworthy, this combines a taut texture with a toast note, showing great depth of flavor. The line of pure green and white fruit is very apparent. On the finish, bright acidity matches the great fruitiness.
title: Domaine Vincent Girardin 2010 Les Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: Ripe plush pineapple laces through the steely acidity of this tautly textured wine. Toast shows underneath all this richness, a subtle hint of smoke, while the fruits open out to reveal a massive wine. For aging over 5-6 years.
title: Louis Jadot 2009 Les Folatiéres Premier Cru  (Puligny-Montrachet)

description: The small production of this wine comes from old vines at the heart of one of the top Grand Cru Chablis vineyards. As such, it has plenty to say for itself, with rich apricot and pineapple fruit and intense acidity all topped by toast from wood aging. This wine is worth cellaring; drink from 2021.
designation: Les Clos Grand Cru Vieilles Vignes
title: 94pointsPascal Bouchard 2015 Les Clos Grand Cru Vieilles Vignes  (Chablis)Cellar Selection

description: Coming from arguably the grandest of the Chablis Grand Crus, this is an impressive, rich and structured wine. It is concentrated, intense with minerality, pure acidity and great fruitiness. The wine has depth and power, a ripe wine that captures the full strength of the fine vineyard. Drink from 2020.
designation: Les Vieilles Vignes Les Clos Grand Cru
title: Pascal Bouchard 2014 Les Vieilles Vignes Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: A wine in two parts. It opens soft, with attractive green and white fruits. Then a tight, steely grip shows through, offering aging as well as a taut mineral character. Give the wine 4-5 years.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2007 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: The seven-acre walled vineyard surrounds the winery and Château. Old vines and a sheltered situation give this wine its richness. Enhanced by the wood aging, this wine is ripe with apricots and spiced pears cut with a mineral texture. It is still young and will be much better from 2019.
title: Château de Fuissé 2014 Le Clos  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: This wholly owned, single walled vineyard is by the Chateau de Fuissé, home of the Vincent family. From old vines, the wine is rich, concentrated and densely fruity. It is also structured, spicy from aging in mainly new-wood barrels. With acidity and crispness along with a steely texture, it will age. Drink from late 2019.
title: Château de Fuissé 2015 Le Clos  (Pouilly-Fuissé)

description: The great flavor intensity comes from the sunny side of Vaudésir. The wine is rich, yet crisp and packed with lemon and apple fruits, a touch of spice and a steely, young aftertaste. It needs to age, so drink this from 2018.
title: Joseph Drouhin 2013 Drouhin-Vaudon Vaudésir Grand Cru  (Chablis)

description: With its perfect south-facing exposure, the Blanchot Grand Cru produces a warm wine. It is opulent, a power of ripe Chardonnay and spicy wood. Combining rich yellow plums, citrus and apricot, topped with wood, this is a structured wine to age. Drink from 2018.
title: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils 2012 Blanchot Grand Cru  (Chablis)
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Pére et Fils

description: Situated right below the village of Chassagne-Montrachet, this vineyard is reputedly founded on a medieval graveyard. This wine is full, spicy and creamy with intense toastiness. Flavors of green plum and mulberries lead to a tang of lemon zest at the end. It is full bodied, ripe and needs to age. Drink from 2022.
title: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve 2015 La Maltroie Premier Cru  (Chassagne-Montrachet)
winery: Domaine Au Pied du Mont Chauve
